PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security: Why is it that under the Minister's administration poverty and homelessness have continued to increase as reported by the Socialist Left honourable member for Melbourne, who is also the State President of the Victorian branch of the Australian Labor Party? Does this represent a failure on the part of the Minister's policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question because it gives me a very clear opportunity to state some facts with respect to the nature of poverty in the 1980s as opposed to poverty perhaps a decade ago. I think any serious student of poverty over the last 10 years-frankly, the Opposition rarely looks in any depth at all at questions; day in and day out it comes into the House with questions that are drawn from tabloids, the latest headline and the latest angle-would have noticed that we have had a major shift of those people who are most clearly in poverty as opposed to the situation in the early 1970s. In the 1970s more than 50 per cent of the poor were the aged. Since the early 1980s poverty is much more likely to be associated with younger people and this is very often as a result of unemployment although this Government has been remarkably successful in reducing the level of unemployment.

ANSWER.PARA: Firstly, in terms of poverty and measures of poverty there is no doubt that the single unemployed have suffered very badly over the last decade. Secondly, and perhaps most importantly, poverty is associated with pensioner and beneficiary families, often single parent families, with a number of dependent children. Thirdly, there is an association between poverty and housing costs, particularly in private rental housing markets. Interestingly enough, if one looks at the record of the Fraser Government and if one looks at the record of this Opposition when it was in government and one asks `Where were the severest cuts carried out by the Fraser Government and which were the groups it targeted to withdraw support and assistance from?' one would find that those were the three groups. It looked at withdrawing assistance from the unemployed; it was concerned about withdrawing assistance from pensioner and beneficiary families with children; and it was concerned about withdrawing assistance from pensioners and beneficiaries who were in private rental accommodation. The facts are remarkably clear at that point. During the Fraser years additional pensions for children declined 34.7 per cent. The mother's-guardian's allowance declined 34.7 per cent. Rent allowance declined; the single unemployment benefit declined 18.6 per cent; and the junior unemployment benefit declined 45 per cent.

Against that, and given the nature of poverty in the 1980s, let us have a look at our priorities and what we have been doing in successive Budgets: Additional pensionor benefit for children-up 60 per cent, from $10 to $16; the mother's/guardian's allowance, up 100 per cent; the single unemployment benefit, up 42 per cent. That is why, whatever people in the welfare sector have said about the absolute numbers and in terms of the scale of funds that we may have provided by way of social security and community services, there has been absolute consensus across the board in the welfare sector with respect to our priorities. Last year's Budget, which contained some relatively modest increases, nevertheless was broadly welcomed right across Australia.

The thing about this Government, unlike the Opposition, is that we are thoughtful about policy and we are determined to establish priorities. That is why the Prime Minister wrote to a number of Ministers last year who were involved in the area of welfare expenditure and said to those Ministers: `It is important that we get early within the Budget process some clear understanding of your priorities'. That is what has been provided so that within the context of this year's Budget we can continue to implement the kind of social reform that has been so broadly welcomed within the welfare community. I think it is about time the Opposition began to give a little more thought to these kinds of questions, rather than to come into the House constantly seeking to point-score around the periphery, around elements that do not go to the heart of social policy in this country.

That is what this Government has been addressing. It has been addressing some of the central issues, which, after all, are to do with the distribution of income in this society. We have nothing to apologise for in terms of what we have done in social security. We have certainly had to make tough decisions, but we have been prepared to live with those tough decisions so that there can be some real distribution, and so that there can be additional assistance to people who have been thrown into poverty by the macro-economic policy pursued by the honourable member for Bennelong when he was Treasurer, when he brought this country into the deepest recession since the 1930s, and also in terms of the Opposition's inability to come to terms with the nitty gritty of policy. I believe that within the broader community there is complete sympathy with the difficulties the Government has faced in terms of the economic circumstances we have inherited, and very wide support for the social policies we have pursued.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Minister aware of reports that the Government of the Republic of Korea has cracked down on the Opposition in that country? What action, if any, is the opposition party in Korea, and others, taking in an attempt to improve the present situation? Has the Australian Government expressed to the Korean Government its concern about the human rights situation in that country?

—Last week the opposition New Korea Democratic Party announced that it would start its signature campaign, the aim of which is to collect 10 million signatures to amend the Constitution to provide for a directly elected president. The campaign is led by the prominent dissidents Kim Dae Jung and Kim Young Sam. The electoral college is heavily gerrymandered to the disadvantage of the Opposition. Full details of the developments are not clear, but it appears that the officials of the CPD-that is, the Committee for the Promotion of Democracy-and of the NKDP-the New Korea Democratic Party-have been prevented by the police from entering their offices. The police have searched NKDP and CPD headquarters, confiscating signature sheets. The police are now threatening action against individuals who have signed the petition. Kim Dae Jung has been placed under house arrest, his phone cut off and entry and exit to his house blocked to prevent his engaging in further activities supporting the campaign. On Monday the Australian Government instructed its Embassy in Seoul to make representations to the ROK Government expressing its concern over these developments. We are concerned at the apparent breakdown of the processes of political liberalisation which we and the ROK friends had welcomed a year ago.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Have recent economic announcements highlighted the continuing success of Government policies, particularly the increase in employment opportunities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Lowe for his question. As usual, he is right on the ball. There is little wonder that international observers are putting Australia at the head of the table in terms of economic achievement. The situation for 1986 is quite clear. The rate of forecast economic growth for Australia virtually doubled the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average. I know that those on the other side of this House take no pride in Australia's economic achievement because Australia's economic achievement spells further doom for them politically, as it should. That economic performance is made the more remarkable because it stands, in contrast to the rest of the world, at double the rate of employment growth. It is the only country in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development which will be reducing unemployment in 1986; there will be increases in the other countries. Our economic performance is made the more remarkable and the more stark when people in this country and the rest of the world compare and contrast it with what happened under our predecessors, because under their stewardship and so-called economic management what we had was the bringing of this country to its knees and the worst recession for 50 years.

ANSWER.PARA: We made a promise to the people of Australia, a promise which was derided by the now Leader of the Opposition. When I said in February 1983 that we would produce half a million new jobs, what did the now Leader of the Opposition say? He said `nonsense', and said it month after month through 1983. He said that this country could not grow, in employment terms, like that. He said that because his whole thinking was moulded in terms that one used the levers of economic power, not to produce equitable growth but to grind people into the ground. It was the underprivileged of this country-the young-who paid the price of his economic ineptitude. He did not have the wit or the economic intelligence to understand that if one applied sensible economic policies one could turn this country around from recession into record growth.

The honourable member for Lowe is right-the performance of this country has been truly outstanding. The important thing is that not only does this Government take pride in that performance but so does the overwhelming majority of the people of this country. The only great tragedy that mars the fact that we are performing better than the rest of the world is that we have this Opposition which, as I have said before, is without talent, without principle and without leadership.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Territories seen recent criticisms of the Government's administration of the Australian Capital Territory? Is he able to comment on whether there has been a decline in the Australian Capital Territory economy since 1983?
—Tell us about the Belconnen Mall. That is what we want to hear about.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most people who have shown a continuing interest in the Australian Capital Territory will be aware of the mess that the economy of the Australian Capital Territory was in in 1983. At the time of the change of government unemployment in this area was running at 7 per cent. It is now less than 5 per cent. The private sector had ground to a halt. There were no serviced blocks available for home builders who wished to take part in that great Australian dream of owning their own home. Land prices were escalating at a very rapid rate because of the failure in the previous 12 months of the then Government to pursue a policy of providing adequate serviced land for those people who wished to build homes.

ANSWER.PARA: The claims of members of the Opposition in this regard are very much like most of the claims they make in this House. They have all the substance of the words of a trained parrot which does not understand what it is talking about and does not want to know what it said or did yesterday. The performance of the present Government in this area since the change of government has been extremely good and compares more than favourably with the disastrous performance and management of this area over the six or seven years prior to 1983. The Australian Capital Territory was one area of Australia in which the former Government played at cutting government expenditure-the supposed razor gang exercise which went on for five years and achieved $300m in cuts.

An honourable gentleman opposite wants to know about the Belconnen Mall. I might say that his Government spent two years and $300,000 worth of public funds in a failed attempt to sell that particular commercial development. It took three years and the best bid it could get was $50m.

I will make one other comment on the sorts of allegations coming from the Opposition. I note that in the Senate I was criticised for failing to encourage private enterprise in the development of the Tuggeranong town centre. We sold the site to private enterprise for development several months ago at a very substantial profit for the Commonwealth. The problem is that Opposition members do not know what they are talking about. It is worth noting that, despite the statements of the Leader of the Opposition that he will cut billions of dollars from government expenditure, his shadow Minister for Territories has given a solemn undertaking, presumably with his Leader's blessing, that in every area of expenditure in the Australian Capital Territory there will be increased expenditure. Is the Leader of the Opposition prepared to underwrite that promise or is his shadow Minister talking through his hat?

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES: EMERGENCY RELIEF SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Social Security. I ask whether he agrees that the continuing wrangling between the Hawke and Wran governments over the emergency relief services in New South Wales is an example of how, in the words of his Socialist Left colleague, `poverty and homelessness have continued to increase' under this Administration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the time that we have been in office this Government has taken extremely seriously the problem of assistance to the States and to the voluntary organisations in the form of additional funding for emergency relief. Since we have been in government funding has tripled in terms of the amount available when we came to office and the funding currently available to the States to assist the various government and voluntary sectors in the provision of emergency relief.

ANSWER.PARA: The conferences of Commonwealth and State Welfare Ministers have involved a number of discussions on the subject of emergency relief. I do not think there is any disagreement between the Commonwealth and the States that in the longer term effective action taken against poverty and the removal of the need for assistance for emergency relief is dependent on overall government priorities, particularly in the area of social security but also in terms of other services provided by government departments. The extent of the consensus can be seen in the major areas of expenditure which the Commonwealth and State Ministers agreed ought to be focused on by the Commonwealth. Those are the areas that I referred to in a question earlier in Question Time where we are providing additional assistance. Our strategy has been very much in line with the strategy agreed between the Commonwealth and the States.

With regard to New South Wales, the Commonwealth is certainly concerned about the decision made by the New South Wales Government to withdraw partially from the provision of emergency relief through the Youth and Community Services Department of that State. However, it is not a complete withdrawal but a partial withdrawal. There have been discussions between the Commonwealth and the States. The Commonwealth for its part has been prepared to make a significant offer to the New South Wales Government. Not only have we tripled expenditure from the Commonwealth viewpoint on additional assistance for emergency relief, but also we have spent some hundreds of millions of dollars to provide additional assistance to individuals in the target group areas and also made an additional offer to the New South Wales Government with respect to the provision of assistance--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is while the people wait.
—No, we have made an offer to the New South Wales Government.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. In the light of the joint announcement this week by the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Housing and Construction, can the Minister inform the House of the expected impact on the local community of new developments at HMAS Stirling at Garden Island in Rockingham? In particular, can the Minister tell the House about the new submarine escape training facility at HMAS Stirling?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. She is very diligent in taking note of the various decisions this Government takes on developments at HMAS Stirling, and she has a considerable interest in the welfare of the Royal Australian Navy people and the impact to those people on her constituency. The Government has taken a number of decisions in recent times to give effect to our two-ocean navy strategy, which we see as an essential aspect of defence self-reliance. Among those decisions put into effect-there are some yet to be implemented-is the stationing of, and providing of the necessary housing and other facilities for, the two destroyers now permanently home ported at HMAS Stirling. We have also taken decisions in recent times to base the bulk of the new submarine fleet, when it comes into existence, at HMAS Stirling and to base a proportion of the old submarine fleet there. They are decisions that will be implemented down the line. When those changes come into effect there will be a substantial requirement, particularly in the housing area, to ensure that those crews can be properly home ported, and some work, though not a great deal, will need to be done to improve the facilities so that they can cope with the additional requirements.

ANSWER.PARA: All of those changes mean substantial work for the local community. The decision we have taken most recently is the decision to construct a new submarine escape training facility at HMAS Stirling, which is consistent with our decision ultimately to base the bulk of the submarine fleet there. A contract worth $11.5m has been let for that project, which comprises a submarine escape training tank incorporating a submarine escape training module, a shallow training module, support services for the training tank and modules, an eight-level reinforced concrete building to house the tank, associated teaching areas and support services, site works and building and engineering services. At its peak some 60 people will be employed on that site.

Of course we do not take decisions solely because we wish to advantage residents in the honourable member's constituency, though they do have that effect. We take these decisions because we believe that they are essential in the defence interests of this country and are long overdue. They are just part of the general effectiveness of the defence policies pursued by this Government. As it happens, these new facilities will benefit many of the honourable member's constituents. I am aware that they are appreciative of that, and the Navy has made an effort in recent times to involve itself actively in the local community. The honourable member drew my attention recently to the Navy's participation in a work training scheme for local members of the community. That is to be welcomed. I know that the Navy is appreciative of the welcome it has received in the honourable member's community and I know that it is also appreciative of her efforts on its behalf.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry will recall during the Mudginberri dispute backing a decision by the Export Inspection Service, which is under his control, to refuse to provide export inspection for meat produced there. Does the Minister's announcement the other day, that following court action the Government will legislate for an escape clause which would allow him not to provide export inspection, mean that the Minister now acknowledges that he had no such discretion at Mudginberri?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, there is no implication of this being an escape clause at all. The Full Bench of the Federal Court of Australia recently handed down a decision. The effect of that, in law, is that the Export Inspection Service has virtually no discretion but to provide inspection staff whenever requested to do so. In that decision the word `impossible' appeared-`. . . unless it is impossible to do so'. That word is not defined, so in all other government departments, if that rule applies as a statement on administrative law it simply means that we have to provide a service unless it is impossible to do so, whether it be the Australian Bureau of Customs, Australia Post or whatever.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the Export Inspection Service is concerned, if we apply that word `impossible' it simply means that we have to employ a lot of additional inspectors, which imposes a cost on the industry. In the usual run of events, requests for inspectors can be made at any time, regardless of the absolute condition of whether or not stock is available. I believe that it is untenable that the people who are accountable for the proper administration of the inspection service have little say in the way this service is provided. When considering a request for inspection staff they must be able to take into consideration the efficiency of the operations, the safety of the staff, together with the effect of their decision on the whole of the industry. It is also necessary for the Government to have an input into the decision-making process when the national interest is involved.

Considering the nature of the judgment-I advise honourable members to read the judgment because there was a plain invitation within it to do what the Government has done-and the added inspection costs that would result if no inspection was taken, not to mention the possible effects in other areas of government administration, the Government has decided to amend ministerial orders clearly to provide a discretion. Under the new orders, decisions taken by officials will be subject to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975. The changes will also enable the Government to be involved in the decision-making process should the national interest be in question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister for Health by reminding him that last year he assured me that progress was being made towards the conclusion of an agreement on reciprocal health care benefits between Australia and the United Kingdom. Will the Minister now outline the stage negotiations have reached? Secondly, will he let us know what benefits this agreement will provide to the many people of United Kingdom origin in his and my electorates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure the honourable member for Kingston that we are well advanced in the negotiations with the United Kingdom for a reciprocal health care agreement. I point out that in the first week of January I signed a reciprocal Medicare agreement with the Italian Government. As soon as the Italian Parliament has approved that agreement, short term Italian visitors to this country and Australian visitors to Italy will be granted immediate access to the health systems of the two countries.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the agreement with the United Kingdom, it is my ambition and hope-negotiations are now sufficiently advanced-to be able to say that in mid-March I will be signing an agreement with the United Kingdom Government to ensure reciprocal arrangements between Australia and Britain. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. In the light of the threatened widespread loss of jobs in the Riverina-Darling electorate and in the rest of rural Australia through the Government's proposed quarantining of farm loss legislation, will the Treasurer investigate the situation in the hope that the existing rural recession will not be exacerbated further by ill-advised Government policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman may say `ill advised' but in fact anybody with an exclusive farm income is not affected whatsoever.
—Of course they are; the values are down.
—They are not affected whatsoever.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question has been asked. We will now hear the answer.

—What was happening was that there was a haemorrhage on the revenue through the fact that many people were not principally in the business of farming but were running a so-called farming enterprise. They were running those losses off against their income in a way whereby they were essentially accumulating a capital profit themselves but were not in the business of producing or relying principally on an agricultural income.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government designed this rule in this way because there was a history of losses in agricultural income for the previous five years being aggregated against other income. To provide for somebody who had a property and was relying principally upon that and was earning some off-farm income, we amended the original proposal in the tax reform package from a maximum of $15,000 tapering off to $30,000 to a maximum of $20,000 tapering off to $40,000. This meant that for someone with an income of $20,000 there would be a full offset, tapering off for single incomes to $40,000-of course, with a two income family that figure would increase. So the person earning some off-farm income who has needed that off-farm income is taken care of under the provision and someone who has a record of farm income for the previous five years can offset the value of the cumulative previous five years farm income against other income.

What has happened is that over years the rorters of the National Party and the Liberal Party have been responsible for breaking up decent pieces of agricultural land into 50 and 100 acre lots. They have been responsible for the speculation in rural properties. The result has been that there has been inflation in land values which has had no correlation whatever to the capacity of that land to produce income. Every Pitt Street farmer who wanted to diminish his income and store up a capital gain was able to do so under this provision. What we say about it is that any farmer who relies solely on farm income will not be affected.
Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you go and read it, you clot.

—Order! The House will come to order. The behaviour this afternoon is deteriorating. I suggest that members ask their questions and then listen to the answers. I suggest that the honourable member for Mackellar cease interjecting.
—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: I ask that the offensive term used by the Treasurer be withdrawn.
—If the Treasurer used an offensive term, I ask him to withdraw it.
—I withdraw. I would not hurt his feelings, not for quids. The fact is that a farmer relying exclusively on farm income is not affected.
—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: Can you inform the House whether the Treasurer withdrew the remark?
—The Treasurer withdrew his comment.

—Of course I did. I would not offend old Rosie over there. The provisions take care of farms which rely upon some off-farm income. The Leader of the Opposition keeps talking about values, putting in his little tuppence worth. I do not suppose that it has occurred to him that the decline in farm prices around the world has had some impact on land values. The fact is that the distortions which are claimed by implication in the question and by members of the National Party and the Liberal Party are blatant distortions aimed at frightening the farm community. A farmer who relies exclusively on farm income is not affected at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism aware of reports in the Australian today pointing out that a doctor appointed to the 1986 Commonwealth Games team has publicly advocated the use of anabolic steroids by athletes? Can the Minister inform the House whether these reports have any substance? What measures does the Australian Institute of Sport take to make sure that none of its athletes uses these practices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly read that article in the Australian. It is proper that the honourable member should ask this question because, in his dual role as an eminent doctor of medicine and a former captain of the world champion Australian hockey team, he has been a very outspoken advocate of drug free sport. I congratulate him on that. It is axiomatic that I and the Government find the use of anabolic steroids in any form in sport totally unacceptable. Under the auspices of the Australian Sports Commission, I set up a committee under the national program of drugs in sport which has been charged with collecting and disseminating research material to sporting organisations throughout Australia, advising them on methods of preventing the use of drugs in sport. I note with some interest that the Chairman of that committee has written to the Commonwealth Games Association pointing out that the appointment of Dr Miller as the doctor for the Commonwealth Games team, given the article in which he has advocated the use of steroids, is a position which we do not appreciate at all. I would be pleased if that position were altered dramatically.

ANSWER.PARA: The second half of the honourable member's question is concerned about the Institute of Sport. Since its inception by my good friend Bob Ellicott it has adopted a very firm principle with regard to drugs. Any athlete or any coach found using drugs is instantly dismissed. It is written into every coach's contract and into every athlete's contract that the use of drugs is absolutely forbidden. In conclusion, I think it would be fair to say that all sports loving people in this country would be quite happy if Australia were absolutely bereft of any medal in any international competition if the price for a winning performance were the use of anabolic steroids or any other form of stimulant or drug.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hawker,Mr McArthur and Mr Reith.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum. And your petitioners, as is duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space;
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt and Mr Rocher.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent and Mr Staples.

PETITION.TITLE: Koalas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the koala declared an endangered species and given the proper protection of the Commonwealth.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House declare that the koala may not be exported from this country and that urgent re-vegetation of their habitats be carried out. Your petitioners also humbly pray that Commonwealth Government funds will be made available for research into the disease Chlamydia Psittaci which is killing the koala.
And your petitioners, and in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Nehl and Mr Staples.

PETITION.TITLE: Dairy Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that they are opposed to the introduction of the Kerin Plan for the Australian Dairy industry which would destroy the livelihoods of many thousands of dairy farmers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will reject the Kerin Dairy Plan.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Free Drugs to the Aged
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petitions of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth-
That the Federal Government's report recommending aged pensioners pay for prescribed drugs be not acted upon.
The aged are more likely to be using prescribed drugs than others and this outrageous suggestion will only deprive the aged pensioners of money they need for living expenses.
Due to any increase in cost of prescribed drugs, pensioners may not be able to have prescriptions filled.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that no action be taken by the Government on this matter and that free drugs remain available to the aged.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
1. That we are completely dissatisfied with the pricing of petrol in this country;
2. That under a Labor Government petrol prices have continued to rise excessively, with recent Government decisions adding over 8c per litre to the price of petrol in some country areas;
3. The proposed consumption tax could lead to a further rise of 6c per litre; and
4. The high cost of petrol discriminates against country residents who rely on their cars for essential communication and transport.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government honour the commitment given by the Prime Minister during the 1983 election campaign to reduce petrol prices by 3c per litre.
Further we strongly urge the Government to adopt a petrol pricing policy which does not cause unnecessary rises in the cost of petrol.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that they are opposed to the proposals contained in the Government's White Paper for the reform of the Australian Tax System in so far as they relate to the imposition of further Capital Gains and Wealth Taxes.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call upon the Government to reject any proposal to increase the burden of Capital Gains and Wealth Taxes on the Australian people.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Enterprise Migrant Hostel, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

We are concerned that the closure of the Enterprise Migrant Hostel will be detrimental to the long-term settlement prospects of migrants in Victoria as well as detrimental to Ethnic Communities who have settled in the Springvale area. In addition, the long-term development of commerce and industry in the area will be adversely affected.
We urge the Government to reverse this decision.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984.
The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whereas the Commonwealth of Australia ratified the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women in 1983, the Government of Victoria in passing the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 is in breach of Article 6 of the Convention which says that ``States Parties shall take all appropriate measures, including legislation, to suppress all forms of traffic in women and exploitation of prostitution of women''.
That the Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 provides legal authority to brothel operators to traffic in and exploit the prostitution of women and to live off the earnings of prostitutes.

That whereas the Federal Minister for Health has counselled citizens to shun promiscuity (The Australian 26.1.85) because of the serious and sometimes fatal health hazards, the operations of legalised brothels encourages promiscuity and the spread of diseases, including AIDS.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government of Australia having ratified the UN Convention on Women remain consistent in its obligations to uphold the Articles of the Convention and request the Victorian Government to immediately repeal the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: North Randwick Post Office Agency
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that the Post Office Agency at North Randwick be closed by Australia Post. The location of the North Randwick Post Office Agency has been of immense service and convenience to us, and has been in existence for 65 years. It will be extremely difficult, inconvenient and expensive to us the residents, and visitors, of the North Randwick, Centennial Park area, to travel all the way to Randwick, Bondi Junction or the Waverley Post Offices, for our postal transactions, banking, parcel collection and other agency requirements.

This Post Office not only serves a large retired community and working community but also the business community which is vital to the economy of this area, and for our convenience. The 2 hour Saturday trading also helps the working section of the community immeasurably.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of this Post Office.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

S.W.A.P.O. is recognised by the United Nation as the sole and authentic representative of the Namibian people.

The situation in Namibia is of particular importance to Australians, given Australia's position as a member of the United Nations Council for Namibia, in effect a member of the UN, the government for Namibia in exile and therefore has a legal international entrusted responsibility to the people of Namibia, responsibilities which it must be prepared to take seriously in order to bring about social justice, freedom and independence for Namibia and genuine peace in that Region.
Therefore this humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully requests the Government to urgently initiate the following steps:
1. To fund a S.W.A.P.O. Office in Australia, such funding to continue until a free Namibia is able to establish an Embassy in Canberra.
2. That all commercial, sporting and cultural ties with the Republic of South Africa be severed forthwith.
3. That all diplomatic ties with Pretoria be severed.
4. To give decent support to S.W.A.P.O. agriculture and educational programs.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

3. Give dangerously wide powers to an unelected body, and

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives should: Completely reject both the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

The petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth-
We, the undersigned, recognise that every individual has the basic right to negotiate employment conditions if he or she so chooses, free from Union interference of any kind.

We request that the Federal and State Governments introduce new legislation or amend existing legislation to permit negotiated employment contracts as an alternative available to those who do not wish to have a Trade Union acting for them in matters relating to their employment.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek to restore payments to the former level.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military Bases in Australia and Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of citizens of Australia respectfully show:
As a part of the world wide campaign by women in the final year of the United Nations' Decade for Women for `Equality, Development and Peace' (1976-1985)
and
in view of the grave possibility of nuclear catastrophe, the Union of Australian Women calls on the Australian Government to:
intensify its efforts for nuclear disarmament.
remove U.S. bases from Australian soil.
keep the Pacific and Indian Oceans nuclear free.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established which will work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and full employment. This Initiative will help to ensure a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover. By achieving these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world to follow.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
2. Implement Action Programs leading up to 1989 which will include:
(a) Actively supporting the International Year of Peace in 1986 by reallocating at least 10 per cent of our military expenditure to fund environmental repair programs.

(b) Implementing National Recycling Programs to reuse water, and to compost into hygienic humus all presently wasted organic garbage and sewage-sludge mixed with fine ground powder from mineral rich gravels and rocks, to use as a natural fertiliser in revitalising impoverished soils;
(c) Developing National Employment Programs to give priority to the planting and growing of healthy forests, food-producing trees and other crops and vegetation to assist the greening of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
This petition of Australian residents shows that we strongly oppose the introduction of the `Australia Card' or any form of compulsory identity cards.

We believe that the introduction of Identity cards will erode civil liberties; will create an increased risk of invasion of privacy; and will not result in any significant increase in Government revenue.
We call on the Parliament to immediately reject any proposals for the introduction of compulsory Identity cards.

The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the wild horses of Queensland and the Northern Territory declared a protected species.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House set aside a National Park for these horses and ensure that killing of feral animals be undertaken in a humane manner with proper legislation and enforcement.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Entertainment Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's total disallowance of tax deductibility for entertainment and hospitality expenses will unfairly penalise Australian business and cost thousands of jobs for young and unskilled people.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Abandon its total ban on entertainment expenses and allow tax deductibility for legitimate and necessary expenses.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Depreciation on Buildings
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's ban on negative gearing and restrictions on property depreciation will adversely affect thousands of disadvantaged people who rent their homes.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: End its ill-considered and discriminatory policy on rented property and allow depreciation on all buildings used to produce rental income.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The implications of the revolt of the gang of seven Ministers on the Government's ability to honour its promises on petrol price reductions and tax cuts.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning's Press is absolutely chock-a-block full of stories of one of the most serious revolts the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has faced within his own Ministry since he became Prime Minister in March 1983. Despite the fact that the Government faces a very severe budgetary problem because of its own stupid, unaffordable promises in a wide range of areas, and despite the fact that, unlike the first three Keating Budgets, the next Keating Budget, the fourth Keating Budget, will need to bear down very heavily on government spending, seven Ministers, who comprise one quarter of the Federal Ministry and who are responsible between them for about 40 per cent of all government spending, have, in effect, told the Prime Minister to go and get lost. In reality that is what has happened.

SPEECH.PARA: The significance of what was revealed in the Press this morning and what was left undenied at Question Time today lies in the defiance that it represents towards the Prime Minister and also in the threat it poses towards the capacity of the Government to deliver, not only on the promised tax cuts that were made in September last year but also on the promises that it made-promises made not only in opposition but also in government-that it would deliver to the Australian public the full benefit of the fall in the world price of oil. What the gang of seven Ministers is saying to the Prime Minister and to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), and, therefore to the Australian public, is that there is no hope on earth that the Hawke Government will be able to honour both of those promises. Unless significant spending cuts are achieved in the next Budget which are beyond the spending cuts that have been achieved in the past by the biggest spending Treasurer in Australia's history-the Treasurer who now sits at the table-there is no hope on earth of this Government delivering on both of those promises, unless, of course, it decides upon a major increase in the size of the deficit. That would have adverse effects on the attitudes of the financial markets towards the Government and the attitudes of the financial markets towards interest rates and the value of the dollar.

The Minister who really gave the game away was none other than the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett). When he was asked yesterday whether the Medicare levy was going to go up and whether he could give an assurance that it was going to go up he admitted that the matter was before the Budget Cabinet. Therefore, it is not surprising that these seven Ministers, none of whom belong to the Prime Minister's faction, have all said publicly that as far as they are concerned the promises of the Prime Minister and of the Treasurer are disposable. By saying what they have said and by taking the stand they have taken these Ministers are making it impossible for the Prime Minister and the Treasurer to deliver on the promises that both of those gentlemen have made.

This Prime Minister is now building up the most unenviable record, as far as broken promises are concerned, of any political leader in Australia. The present Prime Minister of this country is on the way to breaking more promises as a Prime Minister than he destroyed jobs as President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. That would have to be a pretty fair record because, while President of the ACTU, he did more to destroy the international competitiveness of Australian industry than anybody else. He treated the Australian public, and particularly Australian farmers, to one of the greatest exercises in hand-wringing hypocrisy ever seen a couple of weeks ago when he visited three families and pretended to care about the rural plight. After what he did to the competitiveness of Australian agriculture, after what he did to the export incomes of all Australian exporters and after the strikes that he encouraged and supported that tied up our export industries and left the produce of our farmers rotting on the wharves because he would not use his position as leader of the ACTU, he has the temerity to go off in a pre-arranged gimmicky fashion to three families and pretend that he is really interested in the plight of the rural producer, the plight of the Australian farmer.

The fact is that this Prime Minister is on the way to getting back into the Guinness Book of Records yet again. He is on the way to getting into the Guinness Book of Records of broken promises by a Prime Minister. Remember this man. Remember him before 1983. He said to the Australian public: `Let me tell you in terms that even the Liberal and National parties can understand; there will be no capital gains tax'. That promise was disposed of. Then he said to the Australian pensioners: `We will not affect the value of your pension'. We all know what happened to that promise. Then the Prime Minister let himself loose. He really extended himself when it came to the matter of interest rates. He and his mate, the Treasurer, said: `We will do something about interest rates. We will make some promises about them'. In the face of that, one would think that the Prime Minister might have learned something-having promised that there would be no capital gains tax and breaking that promise; having promised that pensioners' assets would be left alone and breaking that promise, and having promised that interest rates would come down and breaking that promise. I do not think that anybody is prepared to wear the argument that only Senator Evans knew about it and that he had an exclusive insight into the workings of world oil markets that was denied to everybody else. Wilfully and knowing the risk involved, the Treasurer and his colleague the Prime Minister, his factional ally, went ahead, misled the Australian public and said: `Trust us. DEBATE.TITLE: PROTECTION OF MOVABLE CULTURAL HERITAGE BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 February, on motion by Mr Cohen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying last night, before I was rudely interrupted by time, when we look at what has happened in Australia, we see that in 1954 Australia's world lead in computers was stifled by a government that believed our culture was not mature or not confident enough to survive. SPEECH.PARA: I believe that these remarks are germane to the protection of our portable cultural heritage. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The subject of this debate is the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill 1985. I listened last night and in the last few minutes to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), and I do not dispute some of his claims. I thought he raised some extremely interesting aspects of our heritage. Of course, at one stage yesterday evening he complained about the lost heritage of innovation, particularly in respect of farm machinery, and he pointed out that it was Australians who invented the first harvester, the stump-jump plough and other great agricultural innovations, particularly affecting broad acre farming, on which Australia is so reliant. However, the honourable member probably should have asked himself why Australia lost this wonderful advantage given to us by our inventors.

SPEECH.PARA: I must remind the honourable member that the first ever major industrial case settled in Australia was the harvester case. I do not think for a moment that the Australian work force should be denied the benefits of our inventors, but it seems to me a pity that, in pursuing its own aims, it has somehow lost the right to build harvesters, which are now nearly all imported, as the honourable member and I know. Some time, I think, the work force will agree that it has been ill advised in this area and that we are building a new heritage of `play now, pay later'. It is a heritage which, unfortunately, Australia Incorporated may wish to scrub out of its heritage of the future.

This legislation is interesting and has the support of the Opposition, but nevertheless it deserves comment, because there are aspects of it that, in my mind, need comment. For a start, it is interesting for me to note that in some ways this legislation could have been of considerable help to people in my electorate. I have talked to the brothers of the Benedictine Community, New Norcia. Admittedly in their case they were the victims of theft, when, in broad daylight, thieves assaulted the curator of their museum, which is an art gallery, and stole extremely aged and valuable paintings which have been displayed in the monastery for many years. It was fortunate and a great credit to the Australian Federal Police that the people who stole those items of art and culture were apprehended before they left the country. No doubt, as they were stolen, there would have been opportunities to have them returned had they been discovered in the countries for which they were destined. On the other hand, however, I see advantages under this legislation, as reciprocal agreements are made, in the expedition of those sorts of arrangements. I note that the Minister in his second reading speech was at pains to point out that in some instances the systematic looting of cultural treasures is known to be organised by black market operators in big buying centres. This theft was a form of that-it was theft carried out purely and simply to make those treasures available to other people. I am sure we are all quite pleased that this legislation will protect that sort of movement of treasures.

Another aspect where the legislation could apply-no doubt its introduction has been facilitated by this-is the recent removal of the Strehlow collection of Aboriginal artefacts from Australia. The Government expressed great concern about that. I have talked to various people who had an interest in that matter. This was a slightly different situation. The concern of the trustees was that the collection was going to be stolen from them by the Government and that they had to be protected in performing their responsibilities as trustees. Let us hope that this legislation is not used in that fashion. The trustees, in their own words, had no faith in the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding), who has just moved to the table. He is not responsible for this Bill but he is certainly responsible for the protection of Aboriginal artefacts. The trustees distrusted the Minister and his motives and the motives of some of his officers to the point that they spirited that collection out of Australia. As I say, let us hope that this legislation is not used in that fashion at any time because that would be most unfortunate and not what we in the Opposition perceive as its use.

In that regard, I again refer to the Minister's second reading speech, where he said that the Canadian experience is that we need not to be too worried about how it will work, that Canada's experience with similar legislation is that, in any given year, fewer than 20 objects are prevented from export. The obligation to ensure that we not try to keep things for keeping's sake must reside with the committee that the Minister proposes to create. Objects that we keep must be of genuine and substantial heritage value.

It must be remembered that people are often forced, if I might use the comparison, to hock the family jewels or family assets which may be of a heritage nature. There are plenty of examples of this in our rural areas at the moment. When people are under great financial pressure, which is probably the only occasion on which they would seek to dispose of these treasures-they are as much treasures to them as they are treasures to the nation-it is imperative that the Government has the means to expedite it so that those people are not the losers from this type of activity. Recently within my own electorate a farmer was on a hunger strike. His only crime was to discover a botanical rarity on his property. His real crime was that he was silly enough to tell the authorities about it. They came in, fenced off half his farm and told him that he would have to live with it. To gain eventual justice-in this case he was dealing with State authorities-he has to go on a hunger strike.

We must realise that when we create this sort of legislation those who have the task of administering it must carefully consider their responsibilities in these regards. If people do apply to transfer goods overseas because there is a ready market there and the committee that the Minister proposes to create is of the belief that they should be retained in Australia it should act expeditiously to ensure that people can get adequate compensation. There will be the occasion when these things are sold for pure capital gain by people who may have plenty of money, but there will certainly be occasions when there is a great need. When that need exists it is imperative that those involved do not delay the activities that occur. These are some of the positions that I take in commenting upon this legislation. As time goes by we will be able to have reciprocal arrangements with foreign countries and expedite their interests in recovering items removed from their countries, and that is what international understanding is all about. I believe that can do nothing but good for Australia in its relationship with other countries.

I do not want to take a huge amount of the Parliament's time on this issue. In fact, I wish to state my reasons for that. It is notable, as it has been notable in the past, that this legislation, as important as it is in its own way, would not normally rate eight speakers a side and 20 minutes for each speaker. I note that the Community Employment Amendment Bill which is to come before this House later today has been allocated 24 speakers a side and presumably 20 minutes each speaker. The reason that it will get that sort of exposure in the Parliament is that, as is usual, the Government has not got its legislative program in place. All of the very important issues which I wish to mention are not being debated at this time. Yet as I understand it the very reason why the Parliament was brought back a little earlier was the great importance of those issues. However, that legislation is not available.

Let me say how difficult it must be for the business community, and for the small business community for which I have special responsibility in this place, to be trying still to do business but not know what the fine print of the capital gains tax legislation says. It is more important that we should be debating that issue now.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point!
—I am on the point. The Government has allocated eight speakers to this legislation. It has not touched on the fringe benefits tax, the quarantining of farm losses or the complexities of imputation.
—On a point of order--
—The Minister is wasting his time because I will only take another minute and I will sit down. I am making this final point and if he keeps interrupting me I will just use a bit more time.

—We do not mind about that, Mr Deputy Speaker. I do not wish to cramp the shadow Minister's style in any way, but he is introducing irrelevant matter into the debate on this Bill. —The point of order is taken. I call the honourable member for O'Connor.

—I make this plea to the Government to get on with its job.
