The issue that I am putting to the Government now is that the responsibility it has is to get to these issues which are worrying Australians and to let them know what those taxes mean, because at the moment people do not know. That is the Government's first responsibility. The people want to know and the Government brought the Parliament back early to ensure that they do know. They are matters of great importance to the Australian people and I would be remiss if I did not draw the attention of the people of Australia to the fact that we are spending hours and hours on an uncontested piece of legislation, we are going to spend three times that amount of time on another uncontested piece of legislation and yet we have still to see the legislation on these important issues. People are presently subject to a tax which has not been explained, particularly the capital gains tax.

SPEECH.PARA: I have almost completed the few things that I have to say. I think I have made the point quite clearly that, beneficial as this legislation will be to Australia's heritage, the Minister must be very careful that those who eventually have the power to administer this legislation do so expeditiously. Section 28 refers to inspectors, section 29 refers to identity cards and section 30 refers to search warrants. I am glad all those powers exist when my constituents, the brothers of the Salvardo Monastery at New Norcia, were able to recover their stolen property, property which I think the Minister would agree had heritage value. Section 31 refers to search warrants being granted by telephone. Section 32 refers to searches in emergency and there is reference to the powers of arrest. All those powers are there, but let us make sure that we do not continue what has happened in the past. When people are subject to this legislation and have a financial need to dispose of heritage property that they may own in their own right-I think the Minister will admit that those circumstances exist-let us make sure that they are treated expeditiously and in a helpful manner. With the present situation in our rural sector, where some of these assets are held, people may be seeking to do just that. I thank the House for its time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take issue with the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) who takes the Government to task for allowing members of the Opposition to discharge their obligations by fully participating in the debate and putting any view that they want. This Opposition is so bereft of ideas that when it is sometimes necessary to apply the gag we are criticised and yet when we have legislation-which is of only passing interest to the honourable member but on which he feels the need to make a contribution-on which the Government says `All right, we will let the debate run through' -we are criticised. The honourable gentleman comes into the House from time to time clutching copies of the Standing Orders in order to impress some of his colleagues. There is ample provision for him and any of his colleagues to use the Standing Orders to bring forward by notice of motion, censure motion or other processes available such issues as they believe are their responsibility as members of the Opposition. The honourable gentleman made only passing reference to the legislation. He said that the Government is to be criticised for allowing the Opposition-I remind the honourable gentleman that many members of the Opposition have spoken on this-a full opportunity to debate the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: The second issue which I want to take up with him and on which he is grossly inaccurate is his reference to the action of the trustees of the Strehlow collection in removing aspects of it from Australia because they did not trust the Minister. Of course, that is only half the truth. I have no doubt that Mr Bannon and Mr Little do not have a great regard for me, as they do not have a great regard for any member of the Australian Labor Party, both being members of the National-Liberal Party coalition. Mr Bannon, the chairman of the trustees, was a candidate for office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that a crime?

—It is certainly not a crime, but they were making an ill-contrived political gesture so that Mr Bannon could get some publicity. If he was concerned about the Strehlow collection being taken over by me or the Government he needed only to consult a good lawyer who would have told him that within the framework of the existing heritage legislation that was not merely not possible but it was certainly not even considered. Not a single statement by me or anyone in my Department could give anyone any reason to believe that the Strehlow collection was of great concern to the Government. In order to get some cheap publicity Mr Bannon spirited the collection out of Australia. It is now back. It was the subject of negotiation with the Government of the Northern Territory with the full involvement and support of the Commonwealth of Australia. Just as the honourable member for O'Connor is an expert in the half truth or the misstated fact-he would never want to destroy a good argu- ment--

—I take a point of order. I ask that the Minister withdraw the assertion against me. It is not true and the facts are that the people to whom I referred, by his own admission, do not trust him. There are no half truths about that. I ask that the reference `expert in half truths' be withdrawn.
—There is no point of order.
—I stand by what I said. The assertions made by the honourable gentleman are consistent with the whole range of suggestions that he makes in this place--
—Withdraw the word `expert'.
—No. I say that the honourable gentleman is an expert in the half truth. He will not ever allow the facts to encumber any conclusion--
—The point of order is that I am offended by that remark. I ask for it to be withdrawn.
—It is not an unparliamentary remark.
—The honourable member should go back to the Standing Orders and look again.
—I will go back to the Nicholson inquiry to refresh my memory on what it says about Clyde Holding.

—I would rather stand by anything said about me than the decision made by a magistrate when he convicted the honourable member for bashing an Aboriginal. Let him stand on his record; I will stand on mine. He is the member of this House with a conviction for a very nasty, cowardly and brutal assault.
—Order! Will the Minister come back to the matter before the House.

—I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I allowed the honourable gentleman to move me from the relevance of this very important Bill. The Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill is particularly important to the whole matter of Aboriginal cultural heritage. It strengthens the protection for Aboriginal cultural material. Implicit in the legislation are the special arrangements for dealing with that material which will be included in the general framework of the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: Most importantly, the Bill allows the continuing participation of Aboriginal people and organisations in the arrangements which will be made to carry out the effect of the administration of the legislation. Prior to the introduction of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Bill in 1984, Aboriginal cultural property which was not merely of great relevance to Aboriginal people but to Australia's heritage and objects of considerable significance had been offered for sale on the open market with minimal government restriction or control. Many State governments had certain powers over relics but could not interfere with interstate trade. In spite of Customs regulations declaring significant Aboriginal objects to be restricted export items, there has been no effective policing of these controls. For many years Aboriginal cultural material, including important secret sacred objects, has formed a significant portion of illicit cultural exports.

The incentive for unscrupulous people to export illegally has been considerable, with rare objects fetching very high prices among collectors in Europe and the United States. In the past couple of years, with increased interest in rare examples of oceanic art in overseas collecting centres, including Japan, there has been a boom in underground marketing and smuggling abroad of privately owned material. Increased illegal activity in this area also reflects a response by some private owners of Aboriginal material to the greater interest that government has given to the protection of Aboriginal cultural heritage and to the increasing concern among Aboriginal Australians for the protection of their cultural material because much of this material is related to the spiritual values and collective spiritual security of Aboriginal communities.

When those items are taken out of Australia we are stealing not simply an object which has some commercial value on an overseas market but part of a culture and heritage which are amongst the oldest known extant cultures in the world. The importance of this legislation is that it will now provide the Government with the ability to protect those very significant objects of Aboriginal culture and heritage. The Act will supersede existing Customs Act regulations and give the Government the weapons to deal with trade that takes place overseas. It will give the Minister and the Government the capacity to act to deal with one segment of activity in Australia which does not reflect highly on those involved.

For many years the only agent providing any degree of control over the export of Aboriginal material has been the Australian Customs Service. It has sought co-operation from people like curators and anthropology and archaeology experts in Australian museums to identify material declared to be prohibited exports under the Customs regulations. But it has long been recognised in all quarters that these arrangements have needed a good deal of improvement. There are difficulties in defining categories of prohibited exports and in identifying objects which are subject to restriction. No redress or access to review exists at present for owners of material who have been refused an export permit. The lack of legal procedures to ensure the proper handling of objects prohibited for export is a significant difficulty for both the authorities and legitimate community interests. Most importantly from an Aboriginal point of view, there has been no formal machinery for consultation with Aboriginal people in these matters.

The proposed legislation provides for the establishment of a comprehensive export control list and procedures for expert examination and a national heritage fund to help with the acquisition of important cultural objects prohibited from export, and for associated purposes. The detailed regulations and arrangements will be determined by the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) and administered with the assistance of a National Cultural Heritage Committee.

The key element in the legislation is the provision for membership of the National Cultural Heritage Committee to include a nominee of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. This provision is intended to provide a formal point of reference so that the special nature of the Aboriginal cultural heritage is taken into account. Of course, that nominee will have available to him the resources of the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs. He will be able to call upon the resources of the Institute of Aboriginal Studies and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the various agencies within the portfolio. So, there will be very considerable backup and expertise available for the Aboriginal nominee to discharge his or her obligations under this legislation.

The Department will be closely involved in these matters to ensure that suitable arrangements are devised to ensure that this important aspect of Australia's heritage is protected. It is intended that these arrangements will consider the identification of significant classes of Aboriginal cultural material and the presentation of Aboriginal material in the national inventory, including categories of material which may be embargoed for export, which may require export permits, which may require conditions to apply to permits or which may be freely exported. They will require the establishment of appropriate consultation procedures for seeking expert advice on Aboriginal cultural objects. There is the issue of the acquisition and long term placement of prohibited exports of Aboriginal material and associated arrangements such as public education.

It is extraordinary how the average Australian living in a society which possesses the oldest extant culture in the world still tends to be abysmally ignorant of both the depth and the tradition of that culture and its enormously important and present relevance to Australian society. I believe that the educational aspects that can take place under this legislation will enhance the knowledge of the average Australian citizen and, in enhancing that knowledge, some of the tensions that exist in many places of Australia today in terms of black-white relations will inevitably diminish.

Aboriginal people wish their expertise, their knowledge of their culture and their belief in their traditions to be part of and available to the Minister and the committees operating under this legislation. Aboriginal people wish to establish the classifications for their cultural objects and criteria for control within those classifications. The legislation provides the framework within which these very proper and legitimate concerns of Aboriginal people can be met. It is important that the legislation will enable Australia to become party to the 1970 Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation which provides the basis for the return of cultural property illegally exported to other countries that are parties to the Convention.

One of the aspects of the settlement of Australia was that, because of the unique nature of Aboriginal society operating as it was outside the framework of a European cultural tradition, the early settlement of Australia saw not merely the decimation of Aboriginal tribes but also many aspects of their culture simply picked up and removed. Those objects can be found in the museums of Europe and, indeed, in some very odd places around the world.

The fact that it will be possible, once this legislation becomes law, to go through the processes of having many aspects of that culture brought back into Australia is not merely of significance to Aboriginal people-of course, it is of prime significance to them-but also a matter that ought to be of concern to all Australians.

It is noteworthy that New Zealand introduced legislation as early as 1901 requiring special licences for the export of Maori antiquities which additionally had strict domestic controls on even the transfer of ownership of such materials. It has taken Australia some time to catch up. I commend this legislation to the House and I thank the Minister for the way he and his Department have been prepared, with regard to Aboriginal cultural heritage which is my prime responsibility, to consult not only with the Department but also with the Aboriginal people themselves. This is one of the occasions when not only has legislation which affects Aboriginal cultural heritage come before this Parliament but also have speakers on both sides of the House given support to it. I, therefore, wish this legislation a speedy passage through both Houses of the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to take part in this debate out of a long-standing interest in conservation matters generally. I commend the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) for introducing this Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill to protect Australia's heritage of cultural objects and, as he explained in his second reading speech, to extend certain forms of protection to cultural heritage of other nations. In this country we possess objects which illustrate our history and culture in significant and unique ways. As the Minister said, some of these objects date back beyond recorded history to the deep roots of Aboriginal life. Others relate to the period of exploration and settlement and to the progressive growth over the last 200 years of a distinctively Australian society.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it can be truly said that the decade of the 1980s has been a period in which sharp focus has been on the inevitable and necessary demands and pressures which we place on our total environment and which must be balanced by our obligation to conserve that environment and its resources for future generations. Conservation is one of several fundamental concerns which determine not just whether we survive as a nation and as a race but also how we survive and what sort of world it is that we look forward to.

Over recent years there has been a marked increase in the level of understanding throughout the community by governments, by industry, by individuals and others whose decisions and actions have an impact both on those around us and on the environment of which we are all part. That understanding has led to a greater sophistication in our ability to sustain the finely balanced cycle of use and replenishment which is nature's own survival mechanism. Discussion papers prepared for seminars which formed part of the process of the development of the national conservation strategy made the point that we have not inherited the earth from our parents; we have borrowed it from our children. Put another way, it is no longer acceptable for any generation to base its activities on the use now pay later principle. More and more, as users, we have to pay now so that others to come will be able to use later. That is true not just for our natural and built environment but also for our environment in the widest sense, embracing the culture and history of Australia before and since European settlement. The relics and records of a nation are an important contribution to our total environment, on which we can have such a beneficial or adverse impact.

I am pleased that when the previous Government was in office I for a time had responsibility for the areas that are generally within the responsibility of the Minister at the table, the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, because the legislation he has introduced into the Parliament this week is legislation which forms part of a mosaic, or network of legislation designed to protect that conservation and cultural heritage to which I have referred. The Minister would be aware of the significant role of the Australian Heritage Commission, the environment protection legislation and the legislation dealing with protection of the Great Barrier Reef-legislation complemented in many instances by State legislation. He would be aware also of the initiatives taken both by the previous Government and by his Government to protect our native flora and fauna. He would be aware of the continuing work of the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and the legislation he administers designed to control strictly the trade in native Australian wildlife.

But it does not end there. This legislation relates to the establishment of the great collecting institutions of the nation-the National Library of Australia, the Australian War Memorial, the Australian National Gallery, the National Film Archive and many others. When I was Minister I was concerned, as I know the present Minister has been concerned, at the lack of protection for our movable cultural heritage. While Minister I gave as much encouragement as I could to an interdepartmental committee that was then working in the area of movable items of cultural property because such items do form an important part of our national history and our future cultural development. The committee was charged with the very complex task of examining ways in which more effective protection could be afforded to these unique and sometimes precious items. I said in a speech I made while Minister that I looked forward to receiving the committee's report. Because of the complexity of the area and changing political circumstances it was not until the present Minister had responsibility that that committee's report came to government. As I indicated earlier, I commend the Minister-although it has taken some time; I acknowledge the complexity of the matter-for now bringing into this House legislation which is a step in the right direction. I hope the Minister would agree that this legislation is really only a first step towards the ultimate and appropriate protection of our movable cultural property.

I have spoken of the importance of recognising the wide-ranging area with which this legislation must necessarily be concerned, including collections in libraries and art galleries and in official government archives such as the Australian Archives, in the archives held by the various State governments and in film archives. I refer also to the collections from theatrical and dramatic performances in this country. Some of those archive collections could be regarded as private archives for they have been collected by non-profit organisations trying to maintain a record of the drama produced in Australian theatres. That, too, is an important part of our cultural heritage.

On that point I want to draw to the attention of the House and to the Minister my concern that we recognise that governments should not be the only bodies that protect our movable cultural heritage any more than they are the only bodies that can protect the natural or built environment. Governments will never have the resources to purchase all the valuable cultural property of this country and its people. Whilst this legislation can be significant in the protection of very valuable and especially significant items of movable property, we need to create an environment in which all Australians are concerned to preserve their cultural history. The State of Victoria has just concluded its sesquicentenary and South Australia, my home State, is celebrating its sesquicentenary this year. As a result of that many South Australians, and I have no doubt Victorians and probably Australians at large, as we approach the Bicentenary, will become very concerned about and interested in their family history; they will become interested in valuable items of family heritage such as books and papers, pottery and china, and silver and furniture-in many instances items that were brought here a long time ago by early settlers in this country, or perhaps items brought here more recently by the later waves of immigration. Those items, brought as they may have been from Eastern Europe or from South East Asia as the special personal belongings of people coming to this country to seek freedom and a happy future for themselves and their families, will form part, if they have not already formed part, of the historical and cultural heritage of this country.

At present many people do not know of the value of their own personal collections, or if they do they are concerned as to the way in which they should preserve those collections. They worry that if they take them to museums or libraries they will be told that the only way they can preserve them is if the items are given to them. Alternatively, people are concerned that if they retain such collections at home and as they become older leave them to their children, or perhaps leave them to their children upon their death, their children may not have, at their age at the time they receive those items, that sense of history, that sense of value for the cultural significance of those belongings. I hope that the Government might give consideration through the Museum of Australia, through the Film Archive and through the National Library, to encouraging people throughout Australia, as a result of the education budget to which the Minister has referred as being set up under this Bill, to identify that which is of value in their personal collections and have it assessed and catalogued. Such a plan will not mean that such articles are taken from people; it will enable them to be kept in private collections. It is important that art works, valuable historical documents, family diaries and histories, old books about the early settlement and even the more recent settlement of Australia, when in private collections, be recognised by whoever comes across them as being of value. It would be a marvellous idea if the National Library or the committee that is to administer this legislation or a whole range of collecting institutions were to establish some mechanism whereby private citizens could not only have their personal family collections of cultural value identified and catalogued but also have attached to them some sort of indicator that they have been so assessed. So if another generation comes across an old family diary that looks as though it is good enough for the rubbish tip when seen by someone lacking the perceptive eye, because of its cover and because of a certificate inside it can be recognised and identified as being of significant value. Then it can be handed to a collecting institution or retained by a member of the family, if that family so chooses, in a way that recognises its value and its significance.

Both in private collections and in some of the private museums one of the great problems is that the indexing of our heritage is inadequate. The cataloguing and description on those indexes is insufficient, but more important perhaps is the identification of the history of the items, the provenance. The art world, that world of experts, has come to understand the importance of firstly identifying an important art work and then maintaining a continuous diary of its history, its whereabouts, who has used it, who has had it on his or her wall, and what has been the history of that painting. The history of a painting is sometimes as important as the painting itself, and that is true of other items of movable cultural heritage.

While I was Minister it was drawn to my attention that there was a great danger that many of the early Australian-produced films would be lost because they were on a process that had a lifespan of some 50 or 60 years. So the National Library-now the National Film Archive-undertook a program called the Last Film Search-the last search for films that would disappear because the celluloid on which they were recorded would be degraded to the point that they could never be seen. There is an urgent need for the last diary search and the last letter search because many families, whether they are one, two or three generations removed from arrival in Australia, still have amongst their papers many valuable documents which tell the story of early Australia.

It is important that steps be taken to identify and preserve that history for future generations, just as I think it is important that we, in our own era, should recognise appropriately the value of the history we are creating. That is sometimes more difficult but, nevertheless, governments do it. They put documents into archives and progressively sort them out. Perhaps we should devise a community understanding of how people should similarly preserve the history of their families, the history of their work place, the history of the organisations of which they have been members. The organisations of which they are members today, for example, may not exist in 50 years time, yet they have been of significant importance in the development of the society in which we live over the period for which those organisations have continued to survive.

Whilst some of the other speakers on this legislation have talked about highly important and very significant movable cultural property, I think we need also to be concerned about the cultural property that is held in private collections. We must not allow ourselves to be captivated only by the high drama of the international black market. We also need to be mindful of an equally important area-the wealth of items held by ordinary Australians.

I turn now, very briefly, to focus on a similar concern with regard to the protection of Aboriginal movable cultural property. I, too, had the opportunity of being Minister for Aboriginal Affairs for a limited period. Whilst I was Minister I became concerned about the ways in which very valuable Aboriginal movable cultural property was being looked after. The difficulty is cultural because the culture of many Aboriginals is not to preserve such items once they have passed out of the significant use of Aboriginal people. Yet many Aboriginals, because of cross-cultural influences, are now recognising the great significance of those items. Whilst the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) is not in the chamber I hope that he and his Department will put more and more resources into providing the means whereby the Aboriginal people can build where appropriate the necessary museums and repositories for their artefacts.

As I mentioned earlier, one of the problems with the museums we have is that they have within them many items of great value but the value of the items to some extent has been lost as a consequence of the fact that the history of those items, when they were given and the time the donor made them available, was not recorded. The donors have long since passed on and the history relating to those items has been lost. In the tourist industry we find that many people visit places of historic import in their holidays and value seeing the items in those collections. They will value them the more if the history is appropriately recorded.

Whilst commending the Minister for bringing this legislation into the House, I hope that it is only a first step towards a major effort on the part of the Australian people to preserve their cultural heritage, with particular reference to the movable cultural heritage that is held by so many Australians within family and private collections, so that it can be identified and preserved by those families, and, where and when appropriate, brought into public collections. But the public collections will never be able to hold all that is of value to the Australian nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by complimenting the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) for his comments about opening up private collections and encouraging Australian citizens to forward their prize heritage and heritage considered by some as commonplace to places where it can be shown. I also compliment him for returning that side of the House to a bipartisan debate. I was very disappointed when the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) soured the bipartisan debate by making disparaging and unnecessary comments about why people participated in this debate. The honourable member for O'Connor suggested that people were filibustering, trying to waste time. On the contrary, all I have heard from honourable members on both sides of the House-with the exception of the gentleman in question-is a superb contribution and an acknowledgment of the need to preserve and retain our cultural heritage in this country. I think it can be said, from listening to speakers on both sides of the House, that members of this Parliament are far from uncivilised, uncouth or uncultured.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me return to the contents of the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill. As has been outlined by many speakers, the purpose of the Bill is to protect Australia's heritage of cultural objects and to afford similar rights of protection to other nations as well. The Bill is clearly based on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation's 1970 Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property-and that refers to our national property.

What do we mean by cultural property? I think we mean cultural property dating right back from early Aboriginal times, 40,000 years ago, through European history in Australia, right up to today. Even yesterday's cultural contribution must be protected because we will appreciate it in the future. I will refer later to the culture forming the deep roots of Aboriginal life and society which has developed over the centuries. Speaking of cultural objects, we are not simply referring to works of art, although the cultural heritage obviously embraces paintings, prints, crafts, sculpture, manuscripts, books and other art objects. I think that we are really referring to the full range of cultural heritage material, including archaeological finds, artefacts from Aboriginal life and, as the honourable member for Sturt emphasised, photographs, films and the like.

The 1970 UNESCO Convention and this Bill will protect our movable heritage in several ways. It is not the complete answer, but it will strengthen and be a right step in the protection of our movable heritage. It will do this first of all by stopping the loss of material through sale or even misappropriation to overseas collectors. Others have spoken about that and I do not wish to dwell on it, but I point out that much of Australia's movable culture and heritage is sought widely and earnestly by overseas collectors. There is the constant danger that we might lose some of the most cherished contributions of our past. Although its primary focus is on this illegal international traffic, the Convention proposes other forms of protection, including a national inventory of protected cultural property, support for collecting institutions, rules for curatorial conduct, educational measures, controls on antique dealers and supervision of archaeological sites. They are a few of the things I want to mention in the few minutes available to me. These steps have long been advocated by our museums, galleries, libraries and archives, so we are taking up in the legislation the sensible course that has been advocated for some time by the curators of our heritage.

I want to deal in turn with some of the steps the Bill brings about to protect our movable heritage. As to export and import controls, a national cultural heritage control list will be drawn up, using certain criteria such as age, rarity, quality, monetary value and the extent of inclusion in public collections. The Minister in his second reading speech said that two lists would be developed. List A would comprise culture which was inalienable to Australia-there would be no permission to export that culture. List B would comprise controlled export and permits would be given. Other nations have rights and expectations in this respect, and it is a good thing that they should enjoy and study our culture at certain times. I refer not to such work being seen here in Australia but to its being taken to other countries for people there to enjoy, too. Therefore, we need permits for the export of our culture.

The process works both ways, so that if other nations find that their treasures and culture turn up in our country in the wrong hands we should be able to return those treasures to them. One important statement made by the Minister relates to occasions when the export is refused. It seems that some people in this chamber, and more so people in our community, see heritage as a commodity to be bought and sold-prized not for its intrinsic value but as something to be invested in to make money and profit. In such cases the Minister can refuse export, and the material will be acquired wherever possible for display in a public collection for the appreciation of all people, not just the single owners. This is not new of course. Governments have acted in the interests of Australian culture before, using powers under the Customs Act 1901 or the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Act 1984.

Let me give the House an example of how the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) was able to assist in retaining some of our culture. I wrote to the Minister a while ago when some publicity was given around last April to the intention of a Mr Hogarth of Murrumburrah in New South Wales to dispose of his magnificent collection of recordings of Nellie Melba-a collection of some 135 titles, recorded over 22 years from 1904 to 1926. This was to be disposed of possibly to American collectors. Nellie Melba is of great significance to the area in which I live around Lilydale because it is in the Mt Evelyn region and Lilydale that members of the Mitchell family-she later became an Armstrong-lived and worked. In fact, Coombe Cottage, which was her own residence at Coldstream was in my former electorate and now is in the electorate of the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson). The association with Nellie Melba is strong in my new electorate and there was some alarm among long term residents in the area that we might lose this valuable collection overseas.

It seems that a few years ago Mr Hogarth offered the collection to the sound recording section of the National Library of Australia and to the Performing Arts Museum in Victoria. However, unfortunately the funds were not available so they were not able to acquire it. Mr Hogarth was disappointed that this collection of 78 rpm records valued at some $18,000 could not stay in Australia. The records were made in America, France and Britain and many were labelled in Dame Nellie Melba's own hand; some are studio recordings never published. Mr Hogarth had acquired them over years of collecting; they had cost him from #5 to #30 each.

Here we have an example of a collection that is uniquely Australian, a product of one of our greatest internationally renowned singers. I wrote to the Minister to ask whether something could be done, and indeed it was. He advised me a couple of months later that the collection had been acquired by the National Film and Sound Archive in Canberra. They will not be sold to the United States collectors. I thank the Minister for his intervention and for the role he played. I also asked him that consideration be given to publishing these titles as a commemorative disc for the public at a reasonable price during our Bicentenary in two years time. This is where the Bill before the House is important. It will give an impetus, a drive, an underpinning for saving our culture through acquisition, publication, display and education for the public.

The Minister advised me that the Archive now holds sets of all 156 known titles of recordings by Melba and they are to be reissued as a commemorative project. This is a large project involving a publication set of 50 LPs to be called `Australia's Heritage in Sound', a uniquely Australian production. There will be 20 categories involving music, speech and natural sound produced over 100 years. The Melba recording, the Minister said, could have an important place in this project. I repeat the request that I made last year to the Minister. For the ordinary person in the street who cannot afford a 20-disc collection I suggest we make one single LP. This would be within the pocket of ordinary people to enable them to have a sample, a bicentennial disc of Melba's singing made from perhaps the former Hogarth collection or the other Archives holdings. I put that request again to the Minister and ask him to reconsider it.

I turn in the few minutes available to me to a matter referred to by the Minister in his second reading speech and reiterated by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding), namely, the particular importance of Aboriginal artefacts and culture for Australia. In establishing the national cultural heritage control list to which the Minister referred a committee will be established not only to assist in the administration of the legislation but also to help in the compilation of this important control list. It is a very complex task. It will involve State and Federal governments and the committee will draw members from a wide source-from archives and museums and experts from libraries and galleries.

The important thing is that the committee will also include a nominee of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. This recognises that special provisions may be required for the protection of our unique Aboriginal heritage and, in particular, rare artwork or secret sacred objects. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment will consult on these matters his colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in order to ensure that the administrative arrangements will accommodate the particular needs of Aboriginal tradition and society. It is most important that we do not leave these things to the white persons in our country-that we do not leave it to a European-derived culture to make decisions overall on how we should deal with, display and use these items, and that we educate people about. Aboriginal tradition and society. Surely the Aboriginals are the very people who should be doing these things. Therefore, I am glad to see a member to be nominated by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on that committee. It is to be greatly commended.

It must be said that our culture will be defended and protected only if the people, the ordinary people, are educated as to its intrinsic value, are able to have access to it and to understand more about it. This is even more important with Aboriginal culture. Aboriginals do not place a price on their culture. They do not have a commercial attitude to their culture and to their artefacts. It is important to realise that they see these things spiritually. They see their culture tied to the land. They see their artefacts, their objects with spiritual eyes and are totally against the export of their culture from this country.

Our Aboriginal culture and heritage are one of our nation's richest resources. With the co-operation of our Aborigines, and with the means provided in this Bill, we should be able to tap into that heritage and increase the general public awareness of the diversity and depth of Aboriginal culture. Opposition members, despite their support for this Bill, still say time and again that they regard as a right the buying and selling of culture and heritage but it is also something to be interfered with. They acknowledge that there is a right to interfere with it. I go further and say that when a recognised cultural object or contribution is discovered, through a search or whatever, every action should be taken to have it publicly owned by the nation. The honourable member for Sturt made that point very well. Even if it is not owned by the nation, it should be displayed and made available to the people.

State governments are working very well in this direction. Let us take Victoria which, last October, established an Aboriginal resource centre and keeping place at the Museum of Victoria and developed an education program for schools. The education program will be developed in consultation with the Aboriginal community for the general public and for use in Victorian schools. Two of the only three remaining possum cloaks in the world, fragile feather aprons, vegetable fibre basketry and implements, including boomerangs, eel traps, fishing gear, digging sticks and spear throwers are among the several hundred Aboriginal artefacts from south-eastern Australia held by the Museum and displayed in Kershaw Hall. It would be a tragedy for the Aboriginal people, and for Australia, if the possum cloaks and the other items I mentioned were to depart from our shores to overseas collectors.

I refer to the position in Queensland. In January this year the Minister, Mr Cohen, announced the establishment of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Cultural Centre at Rockhampton. I will not dwell on that, except to say that the project will consist of a museum which will display a collection of Aboriginal artefacts already held by the Central Queensland Aboriginal Corporation for Cultural Activities, along with other historical items. The Centre will include an amphitheatre for traditional type dances and displays and an area where tourists can learn the art of boomerang and spear throwing. The object of the Centre is obviously not to have a dead museum, its shelves covered with dust, but to bring the museum alive, to have a living museum and to show that Aboriginal culture is not dead, not a thing of the past, not rooted in a time 40,000 years ago, but that it is still with us, still developing and very much has a future.
I received a letter from a constituent who had gone to Victoria and who had visited Kershaw Hall. He wrote:

I was most impressed with the many Museum changes, giving a remarkable feeling of vibrant interest and excitement-so different to the stuffy old place of my child-hood memories (late twenties and early thirties).

However, I'm mainly writing to express my disappointment and concern over one particular aspect of Museum display-namely Kershaw Hall-having recently been given to understand that this area is to be used by the Victorian Aboriginal Community for the housing of artefacts, special displays et cetera.

I'm sure that the Museum can play a most significant role-not only in the preservation of items of Aboriginal cultural heritage, but in the education of children and adults of our community on the life of the original inhabitants of our fine country-and how white settlement affected this culture-and the life and times of Aboriginal people in Victoria today.
He goes on, and this is the important part:

I do look forward to the time when Kershaw Hall too, will give an `alive' impression, and Aboriginal people, with pride and dignity, will be able to assist all members of our community to learn about their past, present, and future.

The point is that the right place to display Aboriginal culture, and to educate Australians about it, is perhaps not in our European-derived style of museums but in a setting which is as close as possible to the setting that existed before the white man came to our shores. I think the Rockhampton project is the way to go. I also mention that during my trip to New Zealand last year I had the opportunity to go to Rotorua and inspect the New Zealand Maori Arts and Crafts Institute at Whakarewarewa. I was most impressed with what was happening there. Not only were there artisans and carvers, for which the Maoris are so well known, but also we were able to see a Maori village. We were able to see, in the setting of the sulphur geysers there, the Maori culture and way of life. I would like to see that sort of thing happen in Australia so that the artefacts and culture we are preserving through this Bill are able to be appreciated by the ordinary men and women of Australia.

An opportunity exists for a similar cultural setting in Victoria. The Australian Government is about to dispose of the Army School of Health at Healesville. The Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) has asked me to convene a consultative committee to advise him on future uses of the school building. We have invited submissions. I understand that the Committee can expect to receive submissions from Aboriginal groups and a combined submission from the Healesville Council. the Victorian Tourism Commission and the Regional Director of Education to establish a living museum adjacent to the world renowned fauna park-the Colin McKenzie Sanctuary at Healesville. Such an arrangement would permit the 300,000 annual visitors to the sanctuary to visit, at the same time, the living museum of Aboriginal culture and heritage. Aboriginal studies for school children would be conducted. The land is most important to the Aboriginal people because it is the site of the old Coranderrk Reserve. It is a suitable setting for such a museum. There could be displays and the sale of modern artefacts to overseas collectors who wanted to see an example, not of heritage, but of its reproduction.

What the Minister and this Government have done for Rockhampton, I would like to see them do for Healesville. This Bill and the bicentennial program appear to be ideal vehicles through which to make such a project a reality. Our culture is priceless. It must be identified, retained protected and enjoyed by all Australians. Overall, it must be cherished and shared. This Bill is a big step in achieving these objectives. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to have the opportunity to enter the debate on the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill 1985. I was a member of the New South Wales Parliament in 1977 when New South Wales introduced a heritage Bill to protect real property, that is, buildings and structures. In this Bill the Commonwealth, which also has a heritage Act, is protecting movable property, personal property. The idea behind this legislation is to stop items of immeasurable value which have enormous significance for our nation from being exported to other countries, taken out of Australia's jurisdiction. The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen), in his second reading speech, pointed out that in Canada no more than, perhaps, 30 items a year come within the ambit of similar legislation. I believe that would be the situation in Australia. Perhaps, given the smaller population and the shorter period of settlement, even fewer items might come forward for consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation is based on a 1970 United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation convention. When the Act is proclaimed the Government will sign the UNESCO Convention which not only will enable the protection of items which are not perhaps covered by the Customs Act and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Act but also will operate on a reciprocal basis in regard to items which are spirited out of other countries and which are of immeasurable value to them.

Might I illustrate one problem which has even confronted me in my electorate office, that is, the problem involved in establishing the worth or significance of an object in relation to our heritage. Shortly after I was elected to the New South Wales Parliament I became very friendly with a Mr and Mrs Symes in Concord West, Sydney. Mrs Symes told me that her father had been a Labor member of parliament and President of the New South Wales Labor Council. She was always very friendly. Ultimately, she passed away. During the Lowe by-election I met her husband, Ben Symes, in the Repatriation General Hospital at Concord with the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), the then Leader of the Opposition. We were campaigning and were photographed together by the Sydney Morning Herald with Ben. Ben Symes later died.

The Symes have a daughter who is in the diplomatic corps. She was sorting out the estate from a great distance; she was in some eastern country. Two large framed pictures were left over when the family home was sold and a neighbour who was helping out was reluctant to throw them out. The daughter suggested I might take care of the pictures. One was an illuminated address-it hardly fitted into my car-which was presented in 1920 to the Honourable Edward J. Kavanagh, JP, MLC, the President of the New South Wales Labour Council. The other item was a photograph of the Storey Ministry in 1920 of which he was a Minister. I notice that Sir Edward McTiernan who served in the House of Representatives probably when it sat in Melbourne and is still alive-he is a good friend of mine-was also in the photograph.

Every week I write a column in the local paper which is one of the burdens of office and one of the means by which I will redeem some of my purgatory. In that column I stated that I had received in my office and was caring for a very large illuminated address. This stirred up some constituents in Strathfield who said that their grandfather had been an artist named Whitbread. He had painted illuminated addresses and trade union banners-work which is now largely lost. It turned out that the constituents' grandfather had painted this address. They told the Power House Museum in Sydney, which quickly got in touch with me and took possession of the very beautiful hand painted illuminated address, which was covering half a wall in my office. It was cleaned and much to my surprise and joy it was featured in the Hyde Park Barracks exhibition in Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was there last week.

—It was not there the last time I looked. The people there change the exhibits from time to time. (Quorum formed) One of the hardest problems for Australians is to identify items of great cultural significance and national importance. I was telling the House that when Mr and Mrs Symes died a large illuminated address was deposited in my office and it was extremely hard to know whether it had any significant value whatsoever or to assess its value. I now find that it is an important part of our heritage. It has been taken into custody by the Power House Museum, which now has written wanting to keep it permanently. During my recent visit overseas I met an ambassador's secretary who told me that she was the daughter of the late Mr and Mrs Ben Symes and that she would be pleased if the illuminated address could be deposited permanently in the Power House Museum in Sydney. So that solved a problem I had.

SPEECH.PARA: Other speakers have dealt with the problem of Aboriginal artefacts. Recently when I was in Vienna I found that the skull of a Tasmanian Aboriginal native is in the natural history museum there. This has caused great embarrassment to the Austrian authorities, particularly as they have had a visit from an Australian Aboriginal who was demanding return of this skull. I am sure that many overseas museums are becoming very conscious of the significance of Aboriginal artefacts to the Aboriginal people.

I will touch on several other matters that the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment might note. One is the composition of the National Cultural Heritage Committee. A representative of antique dealers should be on that Committee because these are the people who have to assess items which are brought in for sale. They meet together at auction sales in Sydney, Melbourne and all our other cities. I even think there should be a representative on the Committee from some of the big auction houses in the main cities such as James R. Lawson Pty Ltd. It is not sufficient to have just academics and university people on the Committee; it is important to include people in the antique trade because they not only need a clear definition of the law, but could give much advice to and bring skill to the Committee.

A final point I want to make is the manner in which such items are valued because many of them are very hard to value. Let us take the illuminated address to which I referred or an antique silver belt seen in an auction room in Sydney a few years ago which had been awarded for a world rowing championship in about 1860, I think, on the Parramatta River. The silver belt came up for auction in Sydney. In the last century Australia staged a number of world rowing championships. Rowing was the first world championship that Australia ever held. Many world rowing championships were held on the Parramatta River in my electorate or on the Clarence River on the north coast of New South Wales. When I was contacted about this silver belt I had no way of persuading any instrumentality to acquire it. I drew it to the attention of certain government departments but I still do not know what happened to it. I hope that it was not exported; it was probably sold for its weight in silver and little else.

I want to ensure that a fair, honest method is used for establishing the value of significant items that come up for sale in auction rooms. If an item is subject to notification that it is of great significance to our country, its value for resale in an auction room maybe reduced because it cannot be exported. People who have in their custody items that may be of great national significance will be reluctant to put them up for sale for fear of receiving an order that the items cannot be exported. That worries me because owners may bring forward an item for auction without notice and by illicit means have its value increased in the belief that the Government will buy the items at the alleged established market value. The Minister and his advisers will have to be very careful in accepting values allegedly obtained at auction sales, particularly if it is clear that the item is not really being sold genuinely to a buyer.

I congratulate the Minister on bringing forward the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill. It is based on a 1970 UNESCO Convention. It will bring Australia into line with many other countries that have similar legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-First of all, I commend those speakers who have taken part in this debate. This is one of those occasions where many honourable members have had the opportunity to speak. I commend the Opposition for its strong support of the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill. I particularly pay tribute to the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who made an excellent speech on the Bill yesterday. The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) was his usual brilliant self. I also commend the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb), the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) and the many other honourable members who made contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: I also take this opportunity of paying a tribute to our Ambassador to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, the former Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, for the encouragement, support and enthusiasm he has given to me in getting this Bill up. He is an amazing man. He has not changed. His enthusiasm now is as great as it ever was. He is nearing 70 years of age, and he still pays the same attention to detail as he did when in government. As a matter of fact, I think perhaps we should institute the Japanese system of having national living treasures-and perhaps he should be declared one of Australia's national living treasures. I also pay tribute to Dr Jean Battersby, who did so much preparatory work on what has been described as the lovable property Bill.

As to more serious matters, the honourable member for Bradfield and the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) have raised the question of aircraft exports in the context of the lack of a national aviation museum, which has made and will make it difficult to protect certain aircraft from export. I have personally expressed my support for a national aviation museum. It is important to stress that the lack of a specialised collecting institution for aircraft, steam engines, stamps or any other objects will not impede our assessment, in the first instance, of their heritage significance in Australia.

This Government has a record that is now second to none in regard to the protection of Australia's heritage. As the Minister responsible for heritage, I have been delighted that we have been able to take so many significant steps. I do not know whether even our own members are fully aware of what we have done. The Museum of Australia will be, I believe, the greatest museum in Australia. It is now under construction at Yarramundi Reach. We are about to start work, in the next few weeks, on the Maritime Museum in Sydney, which will be a great accomplishment and a magnificent museum, designed by Philip Cox and Partners Pty Ltd. The National Film and Sound Archive is now well and truly established in the old Institute of Anatomy. Hopefully, we shall start work in the near future on the National Archive buildings in the Triangle. I think that is an incredible record for only three years in office. Incidentally, I understand that we have just passed the record of the Whitlam Government, having been in Government now for six hours longer than that Government.

There is a little concern about the enormous number of proposals for museums, and I think it is unrealistic to expect the Government to implement all the proposals that are around. The aviation museum is probably our next priority. I know that the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren) has a deep interest in that, and I shall be in his electorate this weekend. The Antarctic museum is another one that the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) and many others want to establish in Melbourne. There is a proposal for a migration museum. A national sports museum is a pet of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown). A folk life museum has also been proposed. These institutions are very costly. I think we are looking at $100m-plus for the Museum of Australia. The cost of running them is extremely high. Very few of them can pay their own way or get even remotely close to that. There is a limit to what any government can do, but I think we have an amazing record for only three years in office.

A number of honourable members have made reference to this Bill implementing the 1970 UNESCO Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property and to the Government using the foreign affairs power as the authority for the legislation. It is important to correct both these misconceptions from the outset. Australia has not ratified the 1970 Convention. The Convention and, therefore, the foreign affairs power do not provide the basis for the legislation. It is for this reason that the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) was unable to find a copy of the Convention appended as a schedule to the Bill. Australia has already indicated its intention to ratify the Convention, and that could well follow this legislation; it is not the basis for it.

This legislation will provide a greater degree of sensitivity and discrimination in dealing with the export and import of cultural property than is possible under the existing Customs regulations, which spread a very broad net. This will be very specific. Its effectiveness will not depend upon which foreign countries are signatories to the Convention. The Convention is not mentioned in the Bill. The honourable member for Bradfield asked what progress is being made in ratifying other UNESCO conventions aimed at further protecting cultural property, and he referred in particular to the 1954 Hague Convention. Let me assure him that these are under active consideration-prompted by the honourable Ambassador, Mr Whitlam. We are examining the implementation of the Protocol to the Hague Convention into domestic legislation.

The honourable member for Bradfield and others have made reference to actions being taken to secure the return of Aboriginal material previously exported from Australia. As I made clear in my second reading speech, there is no provision for retrospectivity in this legislation or, indeed, in the UNESCO Convention. It is true that the signatories to the Convention come largely from the Third World, but increasingly the major `collecting countries', such as the United States of America, are joining the negotiations. In the broader sense, by indicating the Government's concern for international illicit traffic in heritage property, this legislation provides a basis for goodwill in bilateral negotiations which could result in the return of previously exported Australian heritage property.

The honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) asked for assurance that the legislation would not affect adversely dealers and private citizens importing cultural property from other countries. The import controls established by this legislation are limited in focus and operate on a principle different from that of the existing controls under the Customs Act. The new controls will be invoked only if the Government has received a formal request from the government of a foreign country for the return of an object illegally exported from it. It is important to note that these controls are not confined to countries which are parties to the UNESCO Convention but may extend to other countries with which Australia has special bilateral or multilateral cultural arrangements. It will not affect normal and legal import of cultural objects. The honourable member for Bradfield and, I think, the honourable member for Wentworth raised the question of the cost of the National Cultural Heritage Committee. It is the Government's clear intention for this Committee to be established on a part time basis. There is no intention nor does the Government see any future requirement for it to change that status, nor to make it an administrative nightmare.

As I said, the honourable member for Bradfield made a superb speech. He mentioned the Batman Deed. It is not one of the `major deeds' which where signed by the Aborigines but one of a number of replicas given to the members of the Port Arthur Association, which was formed to undertake the settlements at Melbourne and Geelong.
