The youth program run by the Penrith Uniting Church was commenced under CEP and the Siding youth refuge has been assisted. Local child care centres have received over $100,000 under the program. The First Penrith Scouts have received more than $100,000 to construct a hall which will also be available for community use. I note in passing that the foreman on that job is an unfortunate man who has lost both his legs but who is doing a marvellous job of supervision on that project. In fact, he has gone on since to start his own business in home renovation.

Local small schools that would not otherwise have qualified have been provided with general assistance. A number of important projects in the community development area have been assisted locally. Local community aids and neighbourhood centres have received a great deal of assistance. All the five hospitals in my former electorate and the two in my present electorate have received assistance under the program for renovations and, in one case, for new work. The disabled have also received great assistance. For example, the Blue Mountains Handicapped Centre was assisted to start a laundry service. Cherrywood Village was provided with $112,000 for a sports amenities building. These are just some of the worthy local organisations that have been assisted. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) might look through those organisations in the Hansard tomorrow and identify those left wing causes that he was talking about before. Perhaps it is the local Rotary Club, the local Boy Scouts or the Uniting Church that he was referring to as these dangerous, subversive, left wing organisations. In fact, they are all very worthy local organisations that have received assistance and I am very proud of the contribution the Government has been able to make to them.

I want in this connection to congratulate the staff of the Nepean zone office of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. The contribution that its manager, Alan Pope, its CEP project officer, Judith Melocco, and her predecessor Cathy O'Farrell have made to the success of the program locally has been inestimable. Those benefits have flowed through to the target groups, the people the program set out to assist. It has also provided very important facilities and services to the local community as a whole, to particular sponsor groups, local councils and, of course, the State Government departments that co-operated in the program. Attending to the needs of target groups provides a less direct, less obvious but, nevertheless, very important benefit to the community as a whole. Unfortunately, the specific benefits to the community in terms of the facilities and services that have been provided tend to get most of the attention. This leads occasionally to a loss of focus. It is very important to remember that CEP is primarily a participant-oriented program and not a services and facilities oriented program. Its very success in delivering facilities and services has led to an occasional loss of focus away from the target groups for whom the project was designed. This has occasionally led to confusion and misunderstanding.

For example, a couple of community groups locally have complained about the failure of the program to re-fund projects which they have believed to be desirable. They have complained about a reluctance in the assessment process to tailor approvals of projects to individual applicants they have in mind. I take the opportunity to point out that re-funding and tailoring in this way are not elements of the community employment program, and never have been. Successful as the program has been, I believe that we should continue to work for better understanding of the program among sponsor groups and in the community so that they understand the nature of the target groups that we aim to assist, and in particular the short term nature of the job. Occasionally misunderstanding will arise.

A particular example to which I would like to refer and which has come to notice in my area in the last couple of weeks concerns the funding of the Blaxland Mall project. This matter has occupied quite a bit of space in the local Press. In fact, over two weeks the Press has devoted 98 column centimetres to the topic. I shall not attempt to cover it all but shall seek to give the flavour of the criticism. In the Blue Mountains Gazette of Wednesday, 5 February, under the heading `CEP ``screws up'' business, says alderman' the paper printed the following comments:
By helping people out of work, through the Community Employment Program, the Government was ``screwing up'' those who were already in work, according to Alderman Ralph Williams.
He was then reported to have referred to the recent problems in the construction of the Blaxland shopping mall, saying:
The idea of the mall was to allow people to walk conveniently around the shopping centre, but how can this happen when the thing takes 6-12 months to build.
We've just sent the fish shop broke, the Chinese take-away is down to half its normal business and I imagine it wouldn't be any different for any of the other shops in Station Street.
The whole thing's a farce, the female workers run around scantily clad and the blokes spend half their time looking at them.
It doesn't make the council look good, most of the community believes these people are council workers and they are not.
CEP workers should be trained properly, before they go on the job.
The general rule of thumb for a CEP project is that it takes twice the time and twice the money to complete.
The Government can't justify that sort of waste.

It goes on, and that is the kind of criticism that was recorded in that newspaper on 5 February. The facts are of course that CEP is not primarily a public works program. Because of parliamentary sittings I have not been able to check the accuracy of some of those statements. I have not been able to check the state of the fish shop or the Chinese take-away, or indeed the dress standards of the female participants, but I intend to do so during the break.

Apart from that lack of correct focus, the basic question is whether there would have been any mall at all without CEP funds. The criticism to a large extent was corrected in the following issue of that newspaper by some of the participants, and in fact by the supervisor. The site foreman, Mr Roy Seabrook, said the two problems highlighted by Alderman Williams, which included a wall and a set of stairs which had to be demolished and then reconstructed, were due to plans being changed after the work had been started. He said that manual labour had caused delays to the mall, with workers having to hand-dig a two-metre deep trench the length of Station Street. Mr Seabrook continued:
We were informed that we had six months to complete the mall and this target could have been met if Telecom and other services connected with the job had been more co-operative.

As well, there had been further delays to the work caused by a drainage problem, with water running off the Great Western Highway straight into the mall. As a result, every time it rained, work on the top end of the site was delayed for four days and workers had to hand-clean several deep holes to remove the water. The article in the newspaper continued:

In reply to Alderman Williams's comments on scantily clad CEP females, Mr Seabrook said he considered their dress to be satisfactory and to council requirements. The only perverts were the passers-by.

The matters raised in the second article are matters for intense debate at the local level and they concern questions of design, supervision and indeed the weather, which even this Government cannot control.

The question raised by the critics relating to the qualifications of the participants raises an important issue. Anyone would admit that, considering the objectives of the program, there has to be a certain trade-off between that efficiency objective and the objective of providing work experience and developing skills. I regard these as simply minor hiccoughs in a program that continues to enjoy remarkable success. I underline the continuing need to restate those objectives and the focus of the program so that they are clearly understood, at least by the sponsors and, hopefully, by the community in general. I commend the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations for his work in the program, for his calm persistence and patient application of reason. I believe those to have been essential ingredients in the success of this program. I commend the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Community Employment Amendment Bill extends the Community Employment Act which was passed in May 1983. As we are led to understand that some $1.1 billion has been spent over the last three years in job creation projects, it is for the Government to satisfy members of this Parliament, and consequently those who elect us to this place, that such huge amounts have been accounted for and used responsibly. Sadly, there are a number of question marks about the community employment program in concept as well as in practice. If I may turn to the matter of the concept of CEP a little later, I wish first to deal with the program in practice. Opposition members will bring a number of specific projects to the attention of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), who is at the table, for his investigation and his subsequent explanation to the Parliament. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) has already touched on a number of those projects.

SPEECH.PARA: One project that is of particular concern has been described as the `long weed walk', where some eight Aboriginal women have been employed to walk along-wait for it-the standard gauge railway line from the South Australian and Western Australian border to Koolyanobbing once a season to search out a certain weed which farmers have been battling to keep out of the State for 20 years. The number of weird and wonderful projects funded by taxpayers continues. Apparently 50 unemployed people have spent up to nine months on the Great Barrier Reef studying the movements of the crown of thorns starfish, at a cost of $1.1m. If these are worthy projects, where are the concrete results? What are the benefits flowing from this large expenditure of taxpayers' money?

In my electorate there is a small town called Boolara bordering on the Latrobe Valley. I understand that a motley collection of travelling clowns and performing artists have been awarded a large sum of money by both the State and the Federal governments. It is difficult to know quite what this group of supposedly talented people does with the several thousands of dollars that have been handed to them. We know only that they make very few performances before even smaller audiences. It is difficult for any single member, indeed for the whole Opposition, to put together a list of the excesses and abuses of this system. Suffice it to say there has been a disturbing number brought to our attention, either within our own electorates or within Australia at large. Perhaps within my knowledge the piece de resistance is a scandal-no other word can describe it-in the Minister's own backyard. I refer to the infamous Footscray Pool CEP project. This has been an extraordinary story which was thoroughly canvassed by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. I shall be very interested, as no doubt will taxpayers in the Minister's electorate, to know the future of this project. We know that the initial estimate of the cost of the pool was $3.6m, of which $2.8m was to come from a CEP grant. The remaining $800,000 was to be raised by the Footscray ratepayers. No doubt they thought they would be happy to make that contribution because of the benefit that would be returned to them. Sadly, even though the CEP scheme was approved in 1984, it remains uncompleted. There has been a series of delays, inconsistencies and confusion. Despite the fact that some $2.5m has been expended to date, the project is hardly under way.

I am sure that the Minister drives past the site on numerous occasions. He may wish to tell us whether even the basis of the swimming pool has been laid. A number of questions which surround this CEP project remain unanswered. I understand that, on the advice from the State industrial relations task force, the State Ministry of Employment and Industrial Affairs has requested that an independent company be established to act as a construction company in order to overcome union demarcation problems. Perhaps the Footscray City Council and, for that matter, the Footscray ratepayers, are not to blame. However, a number of single minded, disruptive unions are to blame. We certainly await the Minister's reply at the conclusion of this debate to the allegations of a very serious nature involving millions of dollars of taxpayers' funds.

Turning to the matter of the community employment program in concept, I have a number of very serious reservations. Australian Bureau of Statistics figures recently released show that an almost equal number of Australian adults are dependent for their income on either a government salary or a government pension. That means that, for every person within the private sector, there is one person within the public sector. In other words, one of the real revolutions attributable to this Government's three years in office is that the private sector, the wealth creating sector, is diminishing. Governments distribute wealth. They do not create wealth. It seems that we are incurring an ever-increasing list of people who are dependent on a private sector which, under this Government, is not able even to get about the business of creating wealth, reinvestment, growth and, hence, jobs.

I was interested to read the figures also released today by the Bureau of Statistics which show that one-third of all workers are employed in the Public Service-a total of 1,713,400 people as compared to 3,678,000 people employed by private companies. Why is this Government, without any apparent gains, spending hundreds of millions of dollars-not only over the last three years, but also in the three years to come-on the public sector which is engaged, purely and solely, in distributing wealth? Unless this Government changes tack and seeks to assist the private sector, we will not have a meaningful turnaround of unemployment figures. Heaven knows, for all the Government's propaganda, for all its proclamation of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development figures, the con does not wash with small businessmen or primary producers. In my view, it suits big unions and, in most cases, big business to adhere to the prices and incomes accord because the unit cost of labour to big business is minuscule in most cases. For the small businessmen and primary producers, it is a very large percentage of their costs.

I regret very much the fact that the Business Council of Australia and other business organisations have sought to criticise the Opposition's yet to be released wages and industrial relations policy which seeks to deregulate the labour market in the same way as the financial market and primary industry have been increasingly deregulated over the past few years. The Opposition unapologetically and unashamedly seeks to assist the wealth creators, those who will take risks for what is only a proper reward. The pouring in of $1.1 billion to job creation projects over the last three years and a similar-indeed, increased-amount over the next three years is misguided and fails to hit the target. The target is creating employment.

One has only to talk to so many of those who have been engaged on CEP schemes to know at first hand their disillusionment. They have spent some 26 weeks with no real training and without acquiring any real skills. No matter how much this Government attempts to dress up the CEP scheme in the same way as it seeks to dress up OECD figures, claiming some mythical 4 per cent growth rate, the harsh reality remains. But it seems to remain only for those honourable members who circulate in the community, who see at first hand the sufferings that the tax regime, not only promoted but also implemented by this Government, imposes on individuals.

It does not behove the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to come into this chamber and seek to put over all of us this grand scheme of his, which has one purpose only, that is, to reduce artificially, and as a short term measure, unemployment figures. For all the $1.1 billion, for all the benefits from the improvement in the world economy, particularly America's economy, for all the breaking of the drought and for all the benefits that flowed from the wages pause, we have the unemployment rate down to only 7.8 per cent-and that is with the greatest fiddling effort that anybody in this place can recall. Where is the long term benefit of the expenditure of such huge reservoirs of taxpayers' funds?

I mentioned earlier that the private sector ought to be of paramount concern in this place. It is not a matter in any way whatsoever, as no doubt some Government members will allege, of attacking people who receive government benefits or wages. It is a matter of balance, of priorities and of doing away with waste, duplication and excesses. It is a matter of encouraging and freeing up the private sector, upon which all of us who receive either a government benefit or a government wage are dependent. Where is the evidence of this Government seeking to assist the private sector in the last three years? We have tax proposals, a capital gains tax proposal, withholding tax that is too widely spread and the quarantining of farm losses-one could list them all-which take away incentive.

Does this country have to hit rock bottom before we realise that the private sector and the efforts of those engaged in reaping rewards to allow reinvestment are paramount? Do we have to hit rock bottom before we turn around the direction of public sector funding? Do we really have to reach the stage the United Kingdom reached after 15 years of Prime Minister Wilson's socialism? Sometimes I fear that we do. Certainly, all the signs are there. We have a foreign debt of some $72 billion, which is some $4,600 for every man, woman and child in Australia. We have a trading deficit which, over this financial year, is expected to be $13 billion, an extraordinary statistic. Australia, a trading nation, has a trading deficit of $13 billion. Our international competitiveness is declining at a rapid rate.

There are any number of measures which this Government can adopt to reverse that trend. Of tremendous and immediate concern to those on this side of the House is the price of fuel. The Government can easily pass on the full benefits of the lower oil prices, not just to fishermen, primary producers and the timber industries but to all motorists. The Government can abolish the fuel price indexation; it can restore a more equitable fuel freight equalisation scheme. The list goes on. The Government can change its economic strategy to ease interest rates; it can back off the 3 per cent productivity superannuation deal. We can allow a clean float to the Australian dollar. Tariffs on agricultural chemicals, farm machinery and parts ought to be replaced with bounties. There ought to be steady, predictable cuts to tariff protection.

These are matters that my colleagues in the National Party and the Liberal Party raise day after day. It is not some dawn of Aquarius with us: Any person, either inside or outside this chamber, can check the Hansard records. All of us have been engaged in promoting these stimuli for primary producers for the last three years.

One of the grossest acts of hypocrisy is that of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who in the last few days travelled like a thief in the night to three isolated properties in the company of a television crew. He has been in power for three years. The disastrous rural crisis has been building up over that time and has hit all of us in the face over the last two years. What is this sudden striking of lightning on the road to Damascus by the Prime Minister? What responsibility to all Australians, not just the trade union movement and a number of sycophants in big business, has he shown over three years? Nobody but nobody is fooled by that type of behaviour, by that type of glossy public relations manipulation. Moreover, nobody is fooled by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations telling us that he will spend $1.3 billion over the next three years on artificial job creation programs that lead nowhere not just for the participants but also for the economy at large.

Many of us feel strongly that there have been serious abuses in this scheme but leaving aside those very serious abuses-I wonder whether the Minister has collated those abuses; we have certainly put a number of them to him tonight-the concept is wrong, the economic direction is wrong. There is no doubt at all that a number of privileged Australians are doing very well out of the Government's public sector, big business, big unions strategy but it is not the unemployed and it is not the young unemployed.

As if this project were not bad enough, as if this project had not been an attempt to fiddle and manipulate the unemployment figures, we have Priority One: Young Australia. A grand promise was made that by June 1986 there would be 10,000 traineeships. That will not occur; that target will not be reached. The figure will not be anywhere near the figure promised. In the country-as is the case with so many other Government policies-Priority One is a total failure. Priority One combines on the job training with off the job formal training. How are unemployed youth in relatively isolated or remote areas expected either to afford to travel or to have the means to travel to technical and further education colleges or colleges of advanced education? The project is a farce; it is known to be a farce throughout Gippsland, where those who live in outlying areas cannot reach educational institutions to complete that part of Priority One. Moreover, union intransigence, the refusal of unions to allow a traineeship wage, has stopped this program dead in its tracks. Priority One is a failure; CEP does not live up to its rhetoric; CEP highlights, and is a glowing example of, this Government's selfish, misdirected economic policy which will not only lead this country into bankruptcy-if it is not already technically bankrupt-but also throw on the scrap-heap the young unemployed and the adult unemployed, those to whom all of us on this side are dedicated to giving the security they deserve.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly hope that voters from the electorate of the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) are listening to him tonight. I hope that they are aware that in recent years over $10m has gone into his electorate for community employment projects and that more than 1,000 jobs have been created. SPEECH.PARA: I am very pleased to speak in this debate on the Community Employment Amendment Bill. I was amongst the many Government members who argued strongly for the continuation of the community employment program. I am glad to have this opportunity to talk about some of the reasons why I have supported the extension of the program. The community employment program is one of the most successful schemes implemented by the Hawke Government. It has gone straight to the heart of the fundamental problem we inherited from the previous Government, which seemed to be at least unwilling, if not incapable, of addressing the question of rapidly increasing unemployment. The CEP tackles the problem of unemployment head on by focusing on the people who are experiencing the worst problems. This is job creation at its most effective. It centres on groups which, according to whatever yardstick one chooses, are disadvantaged in the job market.

During the first two years of the scheme's operation the interest shown by people throughout my electorate of Brand in Western Australia in the community employment program has grown beyond all expectations. Looking around the electorate one sees evidence everywhere of the effectiveness of the CEP. Women and men are working on road improvements. Projects are sponsored by State Government departments in the forests and waterways around Brand. Research projects are helping community groups and organisations plan for their future needs.

I want to talk more about some of the specific projects in Brand in a moment, but first I must put on record my appreciation of the way the eight local government authorities in Brand have supported the CEP. I know that initially many local government officers and individual councillors had some pretty major reservations about the scheme. When I first held meetings in my electorate office to discuss the CEP with various people, all sorts of difficulties were raised, from the integration of CEP workers to insurance and workers compensation. It is surely an indication of the quite remarkable success of the scheme that all these potential difficulties were resolved as quickly as they were. As local councils saw the extent to which the Federal Government was committed to implementing the CEP as an efficient, effective scheme, they were the first to offer their co-operation.

When preparing for this debate tonight I looked at some statistics about the operation of the CEP in the Brand electorate. My statements about the extent to which local government was participating in the scheme are amply borne out by the figures. Out of the 10 projects which have employed the most people seven have been sponsored by local councils. Many councils have also been quick to take advantage of the jobs on local roads section of the program. I am pleased to note that these projects also rank highly in the number of employment positions created.

There is one other group of people who deserve particular mention at this stage, and that is the South West Metropolitan Local Authorities Management Group, headed by Richard Grounds. Despite their limited human and financial resources, members of the group have forged a community of interest amongst people in the Rockingham, Kwinana and Fremantle districts, so that the idea of a regional identity is finally becoming a reality. Just as an aside, it seems to me that one of the most interesting things about the CEP is the way it has been able to work in tandem with other programs. I suppose the most obvious example, at least in Western Australia at present, is the America's Cup defence program. Indeed, it is the joint exercise mounted in this regard that has resulted in one of the most exciting projects in the electorate of Brand-namely, the Armadale Tourist Walk. This project, devised by the Armadale City Council, has the distinction of being awarded the highest level of funding of any project in Brand. I pay tribute not only to Mayor Ian Blackburn and his officers, who helped devise the project and steer it through the various phases of development, but also to Graham Hope of the America's Cup secretariat in Fremantle who provided valuable advice and encouragement during the final stages of the approval procedure.

Let me say a few more things about the way the CEP has been operating in Brand. To date, we have had a total of 112 projects formally approved. Total CEP funds in Brand so far amount to $7,620,075-that is more than $7 1/2m on job creation in just 2 1/2 years. The total number of jobs to have been created from CEP projects in Brand is 649, and I know that my colleagues will agree that this is an extremely encouraging situation. What makes this figure particularly hopeful is that 44.2 per cent of these jobs have been given to young people under the age of 25. That is 296 young people in Brand who have found employment over the last couple of years through the community employment program.

I think it is worth stressing at this point that the CEP is not just a job creation program. The benefit which has accrued to the community in places such as Rockingham, Mandurah, Pinjarra, Harvey and Armadale through the completion of CEP projects is enormous. We have improved foreshores, built better children's playgrounds, restored heritage buildings, constructed new tourist facilities and upgraded sporting facilities-all through CEP funded, locally sponsored projects.

One question that is often asked of me as I move around the electorate is: What happens to people once a CEP project comes to an end? It is gratifying to note that there are very positive indications arising from the data being collected by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. According to a study carried out last July, 61 per cent of people who completed CEP jobs had found some employment during the six months after their CEP project finished. This would seem to be a very encouraging figure, particularly in the light of the fact that the CEP is targeted to priority groups who have had particular difficulty obtaining employment. I know that the Minister and his officers will be paying particularly close attention to some of the statistical differences being highlighted by the data between the various target groups and age groups when it comes to finding subsequent employment. In the meantime, it is pleasing to note that the figures for subsequent employment seem to be improving all the time, proving that the CEP is, first and foremost, a job creation scheme.

I would like to add just one more thing about the effects of the CEP on the people who are employed on the projects. We all know that one of the most difficult things about being unemployed, whether one is 16 and looking for one's first job or 55 and has just been made redundant, is the growing feeling of despair as the period of unemployment extends. Bureau of Labour Market Research data is now showing that one of the biggest bonuses of schemes like the CEP is the continuous improvement in the psychological well-being of employees, even if they have been unemployed for a significant period beforehand. This extends into the period after the project has concluded, making it much easier for people to cope with whatever eventuates jobwise.

Many of my Government colleagues are waiting to speak on this highly significant piece of legislation and I have limited my remarks so that the debate can proceed. However, I cannot conclude without making special mention of the contribution the CEP secretariat in Western Australia has made to the overall success of the CEP in the State. Right from the start of the whole operation, the secretariat has performed extremely well, from the point of view of both the sponsors and those of us who became involved in promoting the CEP in the community. The Western Australian staff have matched an effective program with efficient administration, and the result has been one of the best run exercises I have ever witnessed. I must also pay tribute to both the Federal Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and the Western Australian State Minister, who have shown an unceasing commitment to the aims of the CEP. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In discussing the Community Employment Amendment Bill 1986, we are talking about a government expenditure program that has already involved a significant financial contribution, and which, by extending the operation of the community employment program, will clearly involve an even greater financial allocation of taxpayers' funds. In 1983-84 the Commonwealth contribution to the scheme amounted to $285.4m; in 1984-85 the expenditure on CEP was $409.9m; and the estimate for 1985-86 is $292m. So since its inception in August 1983 and including the 1985-86 estimate, the Commonwealth's contribution alone will have been in the vicinity of $987.3m. Since this figure does not include the 30 per cent State government contribution or the 20 per cent local government and community group contribution, the actual expenditure by Australians is much higher. If we were to add the 26 per cent departmental sponsor contribution figure to the Commonwealth's $987.3m, we would find that over $1.3 billion had been allocated to this particular short term government sponsored make work scheme. It is important, therefore, that we do not embark headlong into further significant expenditure without being quite sure that such expenditure is going to be in the best interests of taxpayers and recipients and that this sort of activity is the best way to overcome the problem it is aimed to address.

SPEECH.PARA: To continue the community employment program for a further three years, we would be asking Australians to make a financial contribution, at a conservative estimate, of a further $1 billion. There is no doubt that the amount will be much more because of normal inflationary trends and because there are reliable indications that the pressures brought about largely through the inadequate economic policies of this Government will cause private investment not to reach its optimum level and consequently add further to the unemployment problem.

The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), in his second reading speech, has said that it is the Government's intention `to continue the highly successful community employment program . . . for a further three years beyond 30 June 1986'. This being the case, it is only proper that the Government should be able to unreservedly justify this `highly successful' claim to this Parliament, whose members represent not only those disadvantaged unemployed persons but those hard-working Australians who must fund all these assistance programs.

The original aim of the program, according to the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations' second year CEP report, was to create `short-term employment opportunities which would provide appropriate work experience for unemployed persons . . . through the funding of labour-intensive projects of social and economic benefit to the community (with) assistance directed to . . . the particularly disadvantaged in the labour market . . . (and) priority given to . . . those persons who had been unemployed for 9 months or more and unemployed Aboriginals, disabled persons and migrants with English language difficulties. A further objective was to provide equal access for women in CEP jobs'.

However, when measured against the program principles recommended in the report of the Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labor Market Programs, the very principles which the Government has supposedly adopted as the basis for the work scheme component of its latest employment experiment, Priority One: Young Australia, the community employment program does not rate highly.

A major problem which is central to the operation of the community employment program is that it focuses on the needs of the program sponsors rather than on the needs of the prospective participants. This is clearly demonstrated through the practical operation of CEP projects, where project design and approval occur in advance of the recruitment of the targeted unemployed. Indeed, it is only in the few cases under this job creation scheme that projects have been designed with the close consideration of the needs of the individuals in mind.

Although a diversity of projects has been funded under CEP there are still important limitations applying to program operators. These limitations occur in areas such as the allocation of funds within a project, project duration and the length of employment provided. As a result, this scheme, along with similar government make work schemes, has suffered from conflicts stemming from design contradiction; that is, between an expressed aim to assist the more disadvantaged unemployed and guidelines which preclude provision of the type of assistance needed for many in this group. Even when the more disadvantaged have a chance of participating in the programs their employment prospects outside CEP may not appreciably improve. Under the current community employment program no distinction exists between those individuals who could benefit from simply a temporary period of employment and those people who need special assistance because of their more disadvantaged situation. Those disadvantages could take the form of physical or mental disabilities, age and language difficulties and the general loss of self-esteem-not just the fact that they suffer from lack of work experience.

In talking about those persons who are particularly disadvantaged in the labour market, I refer to Bishop Peter Hollingworth, whose book Australians in Poverty provides some interesting comment and relative statistics on the makeup of the long term unemployed. According to Bishop Hollingworth, a survey carried out by the Commonwealth Employment Service indicated that 18 per cent of the long term unemployed were unemployed because of physical disability, 13 per cent because of age, 13 per cent because of lack of skills, 7 per cent because of lack of education experience, 7 per cent because of alcoholism, 6 per cent because of lack of confidence, 4 per cent because of minor psychiatric conditions, 3 per cent because of family obligations and 3 per cent because of mental retardation. According to this CES survey 74 per cent of the long term unemployed are unemployed because of some special disability. Bishop Hollingworth argued that these people should not be classified as unemployed. The sad truth of the matter is that under CEP the needs and special considerations of those particularly disadvantaged people are not and cannot be catered for.

An article by Anthony King of the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research which appeared in the National Economic Review in June 1985 suggests that `job creation schemes are not an adequate response to the problems of the long term unemployed'. He argues that this is because the very nature of such programs can go little way to `eliminate the effects of occupational segregation on recruitment' into the program `or overcome the barriers which certain groups face in gaining access to labour market programs, let alone employment'. He goes on to reinforce the points made previously about the inability of the programs to `assist people whose labour market disadvantage stems from causes other than the mere fact of having been unemployed or having no recent relevant work experience'. Mr King concluded that while job creation schemes `may help new entrants to the labour market, the cyclically unemployed or people seeking employment after a period out of the workforce, in their present form they show limited scope for assisting the `specially' disadvantaged `or those suffering from' the effects of occupational segregation'.

It is also the case that many projects fail to teach marketable job skills. Due to the labour intensive nature of the programs, which is a deliberate program objective, much of the work experience is wasted. If a participant is taught to work with a pick and shovel, there is clearly going to be little opportunity to put that experience into practice when modern techniques of construction use sophisticated mechanical equipment. The second year report on CEP from the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations boasts a 75 per cent labour intensity achievement to June 1985.

Further doubt is raised about the effectiveness of CEP by Mr John Burgess, lecturer in economics at Mitchell College of Advanced Education, who said in a spring 1984 edition of the Australian Quarterly:

CEP suffers from one of the major deficiencies of all Australian job creation schemes in that it is short term and remedial and anticipates a substantial improvement in the labour market. This may work for the cyclically unemployed and the workers with marketable skills, but it is at best a temporary relief for the long term and structurally unemployed.
Similarly, Kirby aptly described the failure of job creation schemes over the last decade when he wrote:

. . . with the sudden and dramatic rise in unemployment in Australia in the mid 1970's, manpower programs were used with an expectation they could fill an apparent void in the development of economic policy. They aimed to improve the adjustment process by substantially reducing unemployment through job creation and training. They were not up to the task.

Job creation schemes, such as the community employment program, are not a solution to unemployment, nor should they be seen as such. The overall effect of CEP is to redistribute the burden of unemployment, while having only an indirect effect on the stock of jobs. What is really needed to assist with overcoming the unemployment problem is a greater flexibility in the wage fixing process. Australia has an arbitration system which was introduced in 1907. It imposes a quasi-legal system on the labour market wherein employers and employees must argue their positions in a confrontationist manner rather than seeking positive solutions in a non-confrontationist manner with a view to improving Australia's productivity levels and the standard of living of all Australians.

The entrenched legalistic approach has institutionalised wage costs and pays no regard to the capacity of employers to pay wage increases and condition benefits. It has thus reduced our ability to trade profitably on overseas markets and pays no regard to the value of our currency. The consequence of our inflexible wages and industrial relations system is to reduce the job opportunities available both at a full time and part time level, and also those employment opportunities that are adversely affected by our penalty rate system. Australia needs to improve the present industrial relations system, so that there will be less need for make work schemes, such as CEP.

Still the largest group in the unemployment pool are young people. It has become obvious that our inflexible wages system has particularly discriminated against young people because of industry's inability to pay them award rates. Further to this problem, the existence of an income maintenance system which provides the unemployment benefit relatively more easily than it does assistance for tertiary students encourages, and in some cases forces, young people to become and remain unemployed. It is a disgrace that young people, and indeed those older people who take the positive self-help step of trying to further their education through trade or university courses, are hampered by this Government's shallow commitment to tertiary students. It may well be that students who have failed to gain technical and further education or university places due to the failure of the Australian Labor Party to match rhetoric with action will, in nine months time, be the long term unemployed involved in potential CEP projects.

In endeavouring to ascertain just where these programs are at, I requested information from the State Division of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. Over two months have elapsed and, despite a written assurance that my request for information would be fullfilled, I learnt today, after lengthy phone inquiries, that the information is for the most part unobtainable. The information which I sought involved expenditure, participant numbers and the types of and total number of employment and training programs which existed in 1984-85 and which are offered in 1985-86. It seemed to me that unless one could evaluate the activities of such schemes at a national, State and local level it was pointless embarking on new job creation and employment training programs. The inability of the Department to provide information to me indicates a bureaucracy that lacks the effective capacity to administer any sort of employment training program. In fact, one only has to look at the paper work involved in CEP applications to conclude that the whole activity is bogged down in bureaucratic pencilling procedures.

When one examines a number of the projects approved under CEP, one cannot help questioning just how `worthwhile' certain projects have been. And since being `worthwhile' and providing `demonstrable community benefit' are priority criteria of the program, individual programs deserve close scrutiny. Other members have referred to just some of the very questionable programs where taxpayers' money has been expended and community benefit, not to mention worthwhile participant experience, are not apparent. For instance, there was a $78,482 allocation to the People for Nuclear Disarmament for a five-person, six-month peace bus project. There has been an allocation of $36,766 to the FILEF, which is the Australian operation of the Italian Communist Party, for the construction of new offices and staffing in its information bureau.

The trade union movement, not surprisingly when we realise who really runs this Government, has also done very nicely out of the CEP. The Victorian Trades Hall received $81,640 for four people to catalogue industrial information, while the Printing and Kindred Industries Union received $172,644 to employ nine people to investigate the extent of sub-award employment practices. The Australian Capital Territory Trades and Labour Council received $245,230 for an occupational health and safety program, while $157,839 was spent on a trade union art and working life program. It is ironic that the trade union movement, so exclusive in nature, has benefited from CEP funding, when it is its entrenched attitude that keeps people on the unemployment scrap-heap.
In conclusion, I echo the sentiments of my colleague Senator Short who, in cataloguing the Footscray CEP project in the electorate of the Minister responsible for the CEP, said:
The Australian public deserves and demands total confidence that the CEP program is being properly and responsibly administered.

Clearly, the serious implications of the inability of the CEP adequately to respond to the needs of the disadvantaged and unemployed and the questions that have been raised about the benefit to individuals cause me great concern as this Bill will empower the Government to spend over $1 billion of taxpayers' money in the next three years from June 1986.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1984 the Hawke Labor Government introduced a number of significant Public Service reforms. It did so espousing the principle that public servants should not be discriminated against on the ground of political affiliation. This was specifically provided for in the application of the merit principle which prohibits patronage. Section 33 of the Public Service Reform Act precludes appointments, transfers and promotions being influenced by discrimination on the grounds of political affiliation, race, colour, ethnic origin, social origin, religion, et cetera. Despite this there is growing concern in the Australian Public Service that promotions, especially in the senior classifications, are subject to political influence and there is growing fear, recently expressed by Sir Geoffrey Yeend, the retiring head of the Depart- ment of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, that there is a risk that the non-partisan character of the Public Service will be seriously undermined.

SPEECH.PARA: The recent rejection of Mr John Louttit, President of the Australian Capital Territory branch of the Liberal Party, as financial adviser to the Department of Territories, to which he had been recommended by the Department of Finance, is a clear example of how a public servant's political affiliation can be used not only to deny access to a specific position but, of even greater importance, publicly to brand that person as being professionally unreliable when a government of a different colour is in power. If this situation is allowed to go unredressed it will undoubtedly mean that public servants who join a political party when in opposition may severely damage their career prospects.

The Public Service Reform Act emphasises in section 33 that appointments should be made after assessing the relevant suitability of applicants, having regard to the nature of the duties to be performed and the abilities, qualifications, experience and other attributes which could be relevant to the performance of those duties. There is no doubt that on occasions a Minister or a departmental secretary may believe for good reason that a sensitive position should not be held by an officer known to hold political views which may be in conflict with the duties of the position, in which case departments have a responsibility not to embarrass severely an officer such as Mr Louttit and by doing so place him in a position where his future promotion could be jeopardised because of his party affiliation.

The Hawke Labor Government, through the appointment of controversial people such as Mr David Combe, now Trade Commissioner to Vancouver, has demonstrated that `jobs for the boys' and paying off political debts is of far greater importance than the maintenance of an apolitical Public Service.

Late last month there was another case concerning an Australian Trade Commissioner, Mr Thomas Walton, who was recalled from Milan for the crime of telling the Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, the truth about the limited success achieved in promoting the America's Cup in Italy. Obviously the Minister would have had the man fired had it not been for the fact that he lacked the power to do so under the newly-established Trade Commission. Public servants are not the playthings of an elected government. Career officers are expected to give of their best to the government of the day. The Louttit case suggests that public membership of a political party when not in government carries with it the presumption that a professional officer cannot be trusted to do his duty. For a government which places so much store on the protection of human rights such a situation should be intolerable, yet no action has been taken to protect Mr Louttit's interests. If situations such as this are allowed to occur, public servants will believe that political considerations do influence promotions and appointments. Every public servant, whether he be Liberal, Labor or Democrat, must see this case as a direct threat to his professional career. By allowing such a situation to continue the Government is adding additional credence to fears expressed by Mr Peter Henderson, former Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs, who has accused the Public Service Board of appointing known Labor supporters to senior Public Service positions.
The Chairman of the Public Service Board, Dr Peter Wilenski, himself a former ALP candidate, has claimed that:

The Board and its officers are fully committed to the principle of merit as the basis of selection for promotion in the Australian Public Service . . . which preclude the taking into account of any political considerations in appointments in the Public Service.
It is time he used his power to protect the integrity of the Public Service and practise what he preaches.

SPEECH.PARA: While I was there the Aboriginal people said to me that they were concerned not only about their housing but also about the fact that great amounts of land were being bought up. Aboriginal adults can go to the TAFE college and do fourth form or sixth form-what we would call Year 10 or Year 12-but their funding has been cut out also and so we have 20 to 25 applicants wishing to continue their education. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Consultants Engaged by Ministers and Departments

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 19 September 1985:

(3) What instalment payee tax deductions have been made in relation to all fees and charges paid.
(4) What criteria are used to determine in which cases instalment payee tax deductions will be made.
(5) If deductions are not made, what information is given to the Commissioner of Taxation of payments made to consultants.
(6) What weight was given to rulings of the Commissioner of Taxation on what constitutes an independent contractor.

TALK.START.PARA: asked similar questions of all other Ministers, upon notice, on the same day.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the concurrence of all Ministers, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters has provided the following answer to the honourable member's questions Nos 1930-1957:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Information concerning consultants engaged by each Minister is provided and brought up to date by the Special Minister of State, who reports annually to the Parliament on this subject. The Minister's 1984-85 report was tabled in the Parliament on 28 November 1985. Questions similar to the honourable member's were also asked of all Ministers on 23 May 1985 by the honourable member for Richmond (Nos 1233-1260) and answers are progressively being submitted.

(2) Detailed guidelines on the engagement of consultants were issued by the Public Service Board, in consultation with the Department of Finance, in 1978. A copy of these has been provided to the honourable member, together with a copy of another document laying down the general conditions of contracts for consultancy services. Matters covered in both documents are being re-examined but the work is not yet completed.

Section 2.1.2 of the guidelines notes that Finance Regulation 52AA (2) exempts the supply of certain services from the requirement to go through the usual public tender/quotation processes. The Appendix to Finance Directions Section 25 (originally Section 31) lists the exempted services, which include management consultancy services and a range of other specialist services.

Rates of payment for Ministers' consultants are determined by agreement, with advice from the Public Service Board. Rates of payment for other consultants are generally set by market forces and bases on the time, skill and contribution required.

Fee scales for academics engaged as consultants and persons engaged as guest lecturers are set by the Public Service Board. The rates set are maximum rates rather than usual or standard payments. A copy of the fee scales has also been provided to the honourable member.

(3) to (6) Information regarding the taxation affairs of individual consultants is confidential and cannot be disclosed by the Commissioner of Taxation. The general principles relating to tax instalment deductions from payments of salary or wages are set out in Taxation Ruling No. IT 2129 (released on 19 March 1985), a copy of which has been provided to the honourable member.

Briefly, tax instalments must be deducted from payments to individuals who are employees as ordinarily understood (as set out in paragraphs 25 to 32 of the Ruling). If the payments are not made to an employee as such, then deductions must be made from any payments which are prescribed under the Prescribed Payments System provisions. Where payments are not prescribed payments, tax instalments must be deducted from certain payments made under a contract that is wholly or principally for the labour of the person to whom the payments are made (as discussed in paragraphs 33 to 49 of the Ruling).

If none of the above conditions applies and if the payment is not otherwise covered by the definitions of `salary or wages' in sub-section 221A (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, there is no requirement to deduct tax instalments.

Where there is no requirement to deduct tax instalments from payments made to consultants, principals are not, unless requested, under a legal obligation to furnish information to the Commissioner of Taxation.
As indicated above, matters relating to consultants, including the conditions of contracts for consultancy services, are currently being re-examined.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United States Citizens Employed at Joint Facilities

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 10 October 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In what way do conditions and regulations of entry of United States citizens visiting or employed at Australia-United States joint facilities in Australia differ from those applying to Australians on re-entry or to the entry of other nationalities.
(2) Under what statutes or policy directives administered by the Minister's Department are these exemptions allowed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Members of the United States forces or members of the civilian component i.e. civilian employees of the United States Government, and their dependants travelling to or staying in Australia under the Status of Forces Agreement (SOFA) between the United States and Australia do not require visas for Australia, or entry permits, provided they hold a movement order or certificate of status. However, employees of private American companies working at joint facilities in Australia are required to meet normal requirements for entry to Australia, including being issued with visas and entry permits.

In addition, dependants of SOFA personnel admitted under the exemptions set out above are not subject to the restrictions on employment in Australia which are imposed on the dependants of other temporary residents. This concession is granted on a reciprocal basis i.e. dependants of personnel of the Australian Armed Forces in the USA are also permitted to work.

People travelling to Australia on Australian or New Zealand passports do not require visas and are not issued with entry permits (except for New Zealanders who would otherwise be prohibited non-citizens under Section 16 of the Migration Act).

With a few limited exceptions (e.g. members of the Royal Family, members of the armed forces of Commonwealth countries) nationals of other countries are required to obtain the appropriate visa for travel to Australia and are issued with an entry permit on arrival which would allow either an indefinite stay or a specific limited period of stay appropriate to their purpose of entry.

(2) Paragraph 8 (1) (e) of the Migration Act 1958 provides for a person to be exempted, by instrument under the hand of the Minister, from the entry permit requirements of the Act. Paragraph 11c (1) (b) of the Migration Act 1958 makes similar provision in respect of visa requirements. SOFA personnel and their dependants are included in a class of persons so exempted. The absence of employment restrictions on dependants of SOFA personnel accords with the concessions available to dependants of personnel of the Australian Armed Forces in the USA. The guidelines are contained in the Temporary Entry Handbook Part I, section 9.2 and Annex 23.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications the following question, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has he taken to initiate a study into the most appropriate ways of eliminating sexism in the content of the media.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on information provided to me by the broadcasting authorities in my portfolio, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: My responsibilities, as Minister for Communications, extend only to the broadcast media. In this respect, my Department has not carried out any specific investigation into sexism in the content of the broadcast media.

Nevertheless, I am advised that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) conducted a National Television Standards Survey in 1979. The document is primarily concerned with offering suggestions for ways in which the media can more realistically present women, their lifestyles, opinions, ideas and aspirations. In 1984, the ABT established a Committee to gauge public concern about sexism and to consider what action should be taken. The move followed the release in 1983 of a Federal Government pamphlet on its suggested guidelines called `Fair Exposure'. In 1985, the Tribunal's Research Branch produced a bibliography on Sex Role Stereotyping and Representation of Women in the Media. The Bibliography includes books, reports and articles from journals and conference papers relevant to the presentation of women in the media.

I am advised that since 1980, the ABC has been publicly committed to the principles of Equal Employment Opportunity and combating all forms of discrimination because of irrelevant characteristics such as sex and marital status.

Through a comprehensive EEO program, the EO Unit supported by Management, works to combat sexism in the organisation. Some of the measures taken which deal specifically with the issue of sexism in the ABC and its effect on the content of the media include:
Preparation and issuing, by the Directors of Radio and TV, of non-sexist language guidelines to all ABC broadcasters.
Organising and conducting seminars and workshops to improve the awareness of middle and senior level management to the issue of sexism in the ABC.
Conducting Seminars which address the portrayal of the contemporary `Image of Women on TV' for all staff involved in program production.

It can be expected that, because the percentage of female news journalists continues to improve, and has increased from 19% in April 1983, to 25% in June 1985, and in the same period, the percentage of female reporters in Public Affairs (Radio and TV) has increased from between 25/26%-29%, a positive impact on the portrayal of women's role will result.

With the continuing implementation of a range of EEO measures, there has been a marked improvement in the awareness level of all staff to the issue of sexism, and this has been reflected both in employment practices and in the program output.

I am informed also by the SBS that programming oriented towards women and women's issues represents a significant portion of programs within the overall objectives of the organisation. The SBS pursues the policy of using women in high profile positions not only in programs dealing with women's issues as such, but also across the board in general broadcasting functions, including news, current affairs, entertainment and sport. By thus presenting women in a positive role as part of the total broadcasting function, the SBS hopes to achieve a greater awareness of the actual and potential contributions of women in its overall audience.

The SBS considers that radio 2EA and 3EA services are particularly sensitive to the needs of women. SBS believes that the cumulative effect of its various radio programs on its audiences will result in their becoming sensitised to the role of women in Australian society in contrast to the role played in their own culture.
In purchasing television programs, the SBS has attempted to respect cultural differences in the perception of women.
The SBS considers that by virtue of the varied overseas productions SBS purchases, stereotypes of women developed in Australia and America are automatically challenged.

As a general comment, SBS TV, while respecting these cultural differences as mentioned above, has also purchased some films which directly challenge our own culture's formerly accepted views of women, and other films by women directors. SBS avoids films where women are portrayed only in a grossly exploitative way.

The various program producing companies which have work contracted out to them by the SBS are required to follow SBS guidelines which include ensuring that the portrayal of women and girls should not create or reinforce sexual or racial stereotypes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are there any situations where Aboriginal or Islander workers do not receive the standard rate of pay for a job and the same industrial protection as that received by other Australians; if so, what are they.
(2) What action has been taken in respect of each situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Aboriginal and Islander people have the same rights to award payments and conditions and protection of their rights as all other workers in Australia. Aboriginals and Islanders, however, among other groups, suffer significant workforce disadvantages. They are generally in low skilled or short term jobs or in remote areas where award terms of conditions are less effectively enforced.

Salaries paid by the Commonwealth direct to Aboriginals or Islanders conform to the applicable award. Where the Commonwealth funds Aboriginal organisations or State and local government agencies the salary and wage component of the funding is based on award rates or, in award free areas, either on a suitable Commonwealth or State public service classification or the awards for work of a similar nature or requiring similar skills or levels of experience. It is the responsibility of those agencies and organisations, however, to ensure that the correct rates are actually paid.

Under the Community Development Employment Program remote Aboriginal communities receive the aggregate value of the Unemployment Benefit entitlement of the community members plus 20% of that amount to carry out employment oriented projects designed to improve the social and cultural life of the community. Usually the participants work part-time for award rates.

The Department of Aboriginal Affairs is concerned that wages paid by State and local government authorities and within the private sector conform to the appropriate awards and conditions. There are, however, regular complaints of widespread under-award payments by the Queensland Government to its Aboriginal and Islander employees on Queensland reserves.

(2) My Department has employed Mr Robert Gleeson on a consultancy basis to investigate the wages and conditions applying to Aboriginal and Islander people on Queensland reserves, to inform Aboriginals and Community Councils about award conditions and to seek the constructive involvement of the appropriate trade unions in the introduction of award conditions on reserves.

Largely as a result of Mr Gleeson's consultancy, the Queensland Nurses Union has negotiated award rates for Aboriginal and Islander nursing and auxiliary staff employed by the Queensland Department of Health; the Queensland Department of Education is providing award rates of pay and conditions to Aboriginal and Islander staff; the Australian Workers' Union has successfully negotiated a number of industrial agreements; and the Municipal Officers Association, the Federated Engine drivers and Firemen's Association, the Federal Miscellaneous Workers' Union and the Transport Workers' Union are offering appropriate coverage, assistance and protection to Aboriginal and Islander workers on Queensland reserves.

(6) I am advised by the Minister for Territories that at its meeting of 17 December 1985 the Canberra Commercial Development Authority resolved `to affix the seal of the Authority to the Agreement for Sale between the Canberra Commercial Development Authority, the Commonwealth of Australia, the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust and Westfield Trust Limited at the express direction of the Minister of State for Territories but accepts no responsibility for any of the contents of the Agreement, any omissions, nor for any consequences that may flow from the Agreement and its execution under seal'.

The snide innuendo contained in the other aspects of the member for Denison's question do not merit being dignified with a response, except to say that any person who can read a newspaper knows that I have been on the motor cruiser Ilona in a social capacity, and that Mr Lowy's integrity and my own remain unimpaired as a result of that except in the minds of those such as the member for Denison.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What quantity of Special Drawing Rights are currently on issue and what proportion is this of global reserves.
(2) What proposals have been made recently for a new issue of Special Drawing Rights.
(3) What are the arguments for and against such an issue.
(4) Which countries have so far indicated support for a new issue of Special Drawing Rights.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A total of 21.4 billion special drawing rights (SDRs) have been allocated since their introduction in 1970 and by the end of August 1985 holdings accounted for about 5.3 per cent of total official holdings of non-gold reserve assets.

(2) The question of a further allocation of SDRs was examined at the latest meeting of the Interim Committee of the International Monetary Fund which was held in Seoul, Republic of Korea, on 6 October 1985. The Committee Chairman, Mr H. O. Ruding, Minister of Finance of the Netherlands, reported that there was insufficient support for an allocation at this time.
(3) The arguments which have been put recently in favour of a further allocation of SDRs include:
growth in world trade could be encouraged;
an allocation would lead to a reduction in the ratio of borrowed reserves to total reserves, thereby reducing the reserves system's vulnerability to financial market disturbances;
an allocation would aid the adjustment efforts of debtor countries;
an allocation would not be inflationary: Inflation has been reduced and future levels of inflation will depend essentially on economic policies pursued rather than an allocation of SDRs; and
an allocation would strengthen the SDR as an international reserve asset.
Arguments against a further allocation of SDRs include:

under the IMF's Articles of Agreement, long-term global need is the sole criterion for an allocation of SDRs. This criterion has not been met. Non-gold reserves have grown very rapidly over the last few years;

the ratio of non-gold reserves to imports suggests that recent reserve accumulation has kept pace with the recovery in international trade. The reserves/import ratio for all countries was 21.5 per cent for 1984, its highest level since 1978; for developing countries this ratio had risen to 31.7 per cent in 1984, also the highest level since 1978;
in 1984 the ratio of reserves to trade imbalances for the developing countries group was at its highest level since 1972;
this recent improvement in reserve growth has been achieved without an SDR allocation;

(4) It is not possible to give a comprehensive answer to this question because the individual views of all countries have not been formally canvassed or recorded. The Summary Proceedings of the 1984 Annual meetings indicate that Argentina, Bangladesh, Belgium, Canada, China, Egypt, Fiji, France, India, Indonesia, Islamic Republic of Iran, Israel, Italy, Republic of Korea, Luxemburg, Malaysia, Malta, Nepal, New Zealand, Spain, Sri Lanka, St Lucia, Tunisia, Western Samoa, Yugoslavia, and Zambia spoke in favour of an allocation. The Summary Proceedings of the 1985 Annual Meetings are not yet available.
